		The reference in subsection (1)(b) to scientific research related to theappropriate class of trade includes—
			scientific research which may lead to or facilitate an extension of tradesof the appropriate class, and
			scientific research of a medical nature which has a special relation to thewelfare of workers employed in trades of the appropriate class.
		If a question arises as to—
			whether, or
			to what extent,
			any activities constitute or constituted scientific research, an officer ofRevenue and Customs must refer the question for decision to the Secretary ofState, whose decision is final.
		The same expenses may not be brought into account under this section inrelation to more than one trade.

Expenses connected with patents, designs and trade marks
	Expenses connected with patents
		In calculating the profits of a trade, a deduction is allowed for expensesincurred—
			in obtaining for the purposes of the trade the grant of a patent or theextension of a patent’s term, or
			in connection with a rejected or abandoned application for a patent madefor the purposes of the trade.
	Expenses connected with designs or trade marks
		In calculating the profits of a trade, a deduction is allowed for expensesincurred in obtaining for the purposes of the trade—
			the registration of a design or trade mark,
			the extension of a period for which the right in a registered designsubsists, or
			the renewal of registration of a trade mark.

Export Credits Guarantee Department
	Payments to Export Credits Guarantee Department
		In calculating the profits of a trade, a deduction is allowed for a sumpayable by the company carrying on the trade to the Export Credits GuaranteeDepartment—
			under an agreement entered into as a result of arrangements made undersection 2 of the Export and Investment Guarantees Act [1991 (c.67)](/id/ukpga/1991/67?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (insurance inconnection with overseas investment), or
			with a view to entering into such an agreement.

Levies under FISMA 2000
	Levies etc under FISMA 2000
		In calculating the profits of a trade carried on by a company, a deductionis allowed for any sum—
			spent by the company in paying a levy, or
			paid by the company as a result of an award of costs under costs rules,
				so far as it is not otherwise allowable.
		For the purposes of this section “costs rules” means—
			rules made under section 230 of FISMA 2000, or
			provision relating to costs contained in the standard terms fixed underparagraph 18 of Schedule 17 to FISMA 2000.
		For the purposes of this section “levy” means—
			a payment required under rules made under section 136(2) of FISMA 2000,
			a levy imposed under the Financial Services Compensation Scheme,
			a payment required under rules made under section 234 of FISMA 2000,
			a payment required under the rules referred to in paragraph 14(1) ofSchedule 17 to FISMA 2000 in accordance with paragraph 15(1) of that Schedule,or
			a payment required in accordance with the standard terms fixed underparagraph 18 of that Schedule (other than a sum paid as a result of an awardof costs under costs rules).

Chapter 6Trade profits: receipts
	Capital receipts
		Capital receipts
			Items of a capital nature must not be brought into account as receipts incalculating the profits of a trade.
			But this does not apply to items which, as a result of any provision of theCorporation Tax Acts, are brought into account as receipts in calculating theprofits of the trade.
	Debts released
		Debts incurred and later released
			This section applies if—
				in calculating the profits of a trade, a deduction is allowed for theexpense giving rise to a debt owed by the company carrying on the trade,
				all or part of the debt is released, and
				the release is not part of a statutory insolvency arrangement.
			The amount released—
				is brought into account as a receipt in calculating the profits of thetrade, and
				is treated as arising in the accounting period in which the release iseffected.
	Amounts received following earlier cessation
		Acquisition of trade: receipts from transferor’s trade
			This section applies if —
				a person (“the transferor”) permanently ceased to carry on a trade at anytime,
				at that time the transferor transferred to another person (“thetransferee”) the right to receive sums arising from the carrying on of thetrade, and
				the transferee subsequently carries on the transferor’s trade.
			Sums— 
				which the transferee receives as a result of the transfer, and
				which are not brought into account in calculating the profits of thetransferor’s trade for corporation or income tax purposes of any period beforethe cessation,
					are brought into account in calculating the profits of the transferee’s tradein the accounting period in which they are received.
			Any sums mentioned in subsection (1)(b) which are received after thetransferor has permanently ceased to carry on the trade are not post-cessationreceipts (see Chapter 15).
	Reverse premiums
		Reverse premiums
			For the purposes of sections 98 and 99 a payment or other benefit is areverse premium if—
				conditions A, B and C are met, and
				it is not excluded by section 97.
			Condition A is that a company (“the recipient”) receives the payment orother benefit by way of inducement in connection with a transaction beingentered into by—
				the recipient, or
				a person connected with the recipient.
			Condition B is that the transaction (the “property transaction”) is oneunder which—
				the recipient, or
				the person connected with the recipient,
					becomes entitled to an estate, interest or right in or over land.
			Condition C is that the payment or other benefit is paid or provided by—
				the person (“the grantor”) by whom the estate, interest or right is grantedor was granted at an earlier time,
				a person connected with the grantor, or
				a nominee of, or a person acting on the directions of, the grantor or aperson connected with the grantor.
		Excluded cases
			A payment or other benefit is not a reverse premium so far as it is broughtinto account under section 532 of CAA 2001 (the general rule excludingcontributions) to reduce the recipient’s expenditure qualifying for capitalallowances.
			A payment or other benefit received in connection with a propertytransaction is not a reverse premium if—
				the person entering into the transaction is an individual, and
				the transaction relates to premises occupied or to be occupied by theindividual as the individual’s only or main residence.
			A payment or other benefit is not a reverse premium so far as it isconsideration for the transfer of an estate or interest in land whichconstitutes the sale in a sale and leaseback arrangement.
			A “sale and leaseback arrangement” means any such arrangement as isdescribed in section 779(1) or (2) or 780(1) of ICTA.
		Tax treatment of reverse premiums
			A reverse premium is treated for corporation tax purposes as a receipt of arevenue nature.
			If the recipient enters into the property transaction for the purposes of atrade carried on (or to be carried on) by the recipient, the reverse premiumis brought into account in calculating the profits of the trade.
			If subsection (2) does not apply, the reverse premium is charged tocorporation tax in accordance with section 250 (reverse premium taxed asproperty business receipt).
		Arrangements not at arm’s length
			This section applies if—
				two or more of the parties to the property arrangements are connectedpersons, and
				the terms of those arrangements are not such as would reasonably have beenexpected if those persons had been dealing at arm’s length.
			The terms of the property arrangements meet the condition in subsection(1)(b) if they differ to a significant extent from the terms which, at thetime the arrangements were entered into, would be regarded as normal andreasonable—
				in the market conditions then prevailing, and
				between persons dealing with each other at arm’s length in the open market.
			The whole amount or value of the reverse premium brought into account undersection 98 is brought into account in the first relevant period of account.
			“The first relevant period of account” means the period of account in whichthe property transaction is entered into.
			However if the recipient enters into the property transaction for thepurposes of a trade—
				which is not then carried on by the recipient, but
				which the recipient subsequently starts to carry on,
					“the first relevant period of account” means the first period of account inwhich the recipient carries on the trade.
		Connected persons and property arrangements
			For the purposes of this section and sections 96 to 99—
				persons are treated as connected with each other if they are connected atany time during the period when the property arrangements are entered into,and
				“the property arrangements” means the property transaction and anyarrangements entered into in connection with it (whether before it, at thesame time as it or after it).
	Other receipts
		Distribution of assets of mutual concerns
			This section applies if—
				a deduction has been made in calculating the profits of a trade for apayment to a mutual concern for the purposes of its mutual business,
				the concern is being or has been wound up or dissolved,
				a company (“the recipient”) which is carrying on the trade, or was doing soat the time of the payment, receives money or money’s worth representing theconcern’s assets, and
				the assets in question represent profits of the mutual business conductedby the concern.
			If the recipient is carrying on the trade at the time the money or money’sworth is received, the amount or value of the money or money’s worth isbrought into account as a receipt in calculating the profits of the trade.
			If the recipient—
				is not carrying on the trade at the time the money or money’s worth isreceived, but
				was doing so at the time of the payment to the mutual concern,
					the amount or value of the money or money’s worth is treated as a post-cessation receipt (see Chapter 15).
			For the purposes of this section money or money’s worth represents assetsof a mutual concern if it—
				forms part of the assets of the concern,
				forms part of the consideration for the transfer of the assets of theconcern as part of a scheme of amalgamation or reconstruction which involvesits winding up, or
				consists of the consideration for a transfer or surrender of a right toreceive anything falling within paragraph (a) or (b) and does not give rise toa charge to corporation tax on the company receiving it otherwise than as aresult of this section.
			If a transfer or surrender of a right to receive anything which—
				forms part of the assets of a mutual concern, or
				forms part of the consideration for the transfer of the assets of a mutualconcern,
				is not at arm’s length, the company making the transfer or surrender istreated as receiving consideration equal to the value of the right.
			In this section references to a mutual concern are to a body corporatewhich has at any time carried on a trade which consists of or includes theconduct of mutual business (whether or not confined to the members of the bodycorporate).
			For the purposes of this section a trade does not consist of or include theconduct of mutual business if all the profits of the trade are chargeable tocorporation or income tax.
		Industrial development grants
			This section applies if a company carrying on a trade receives a payment byway of a grant under—
				section 7 or 8 of the Industrial Development Act [1982 (c.52)](/id/ukpga/1982/52?view=plain "Go to item of legislation"), or
				Article 7, 9 or 30 of the Industrial Development (Northern Ireland) Order1982 ([S.I. 1982/1083 (N.I. 15)](/id/nisi/1982/1083?view=plain "Go to item oflegislation")).
			The payment is brought into account as a receipt in calculating the profitsof the trade unless—
				the grant is designated as made towards the cost of specified capitalexpenditure,
				the grant is designated as compensation for the loss of capital assets, or
				the grant is for all or part of a corporation tax liability (including onethat has already been met).
		Sums recovered under insurance policies etc
			This section applies if—
				a deduction has been made for a loss or expense in calculating the profitsof a trade,
				a company carrying on the trade recovers a sum under an insurance policy ora contract of indemnity in respect of the loss or expense, and
				the sum is not of a revenue nature.
			The sum is brought into account as a receipt in calculating the profits ofthe trade (but only up to the amount of the deduction).
		Repayments under FISMA 2000
			This section applies if—
				a company carries on a trade, and
				a payment is made to the company as a result of a repayment provision.
			The payment is brought into account as a receipt in calculating the profitsof the trade.
			For the purposes of this section “repayment provision” means—
				any provision made by virtue of section 136(7) or 214(1)(e) of FISMA 2000,or
				any provision made by scheme rules for fees to be refunded in specifiedcircumstances.
			In this section “scheme rules” means the rules referred to in paragraph14(1) of Schedule 17 to FISMA 2000.

Chapter 7Trade profits: gifts to charities etc
	Relief for certain gifts
		Gifts of trading stock to charities etc
			This section applies if a company carrying on a trade (“the donor”) givesan article for the purposes of—
				a charity, a registered club or a body listed in subsection (4), or
				a designated educational establishment (see section 106),
					and the article is one manufactured, or of a class or description sold, by thedonor in the course of the trade.
			In calculating the profits of the trade, no amount is required to bebrought into account as a receipt in consequence of the disposal of thearticle.
			In this section “registered club” has the meaning given by paragraph 1 ofSchedule 18 to FA 2002 (relief for community amateur sports clubs).
			The bodies referred to in subsection (1)(a) are—
				the Trustees of the National Heritage Memorial Fund,
				the Historic Buildings and Monuments Commission for England, and
				the National Endowment for Science, Technology and the Arts.
			This section needs to be read with section 108 (receipt of benefits bydonor or connected person).
		Meaning of “designated educational establishment”
			For the purposes of section 105 “designated educational establishment”means an educational establishment designated, or within a categorydesignated, in regulations made—
				for England and Scotland, by the Secretary of State,
				for Wales, by the Welsh Ministers, and
				for Northern Ireland, by the Department of Education.
			The regulations may make different provision for different areas.
			If any question arises as to whether an educational establishment is withina category designated in the regulations, an officer of Revenue and Customsmust refer the question for decision—
				in the case of an establishment in England or Scotland, to the Secretary ofState,
				in the case of an establishment in Wales, to the Welsh Ministers, and
				in the case of an establishment in Northern Ireland, to the Department ofEducation.
			The power of the Secretary of State or the Welsh Ministers to makeregulations under this section is exercisable by statutory instrument.
			A statutory instrument containing any regulations made by the Secretary ofState under this section is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolutionof the House of Commons.
			A statutory instrument containing any regulations made by the WelshMinisters under this section is subject to annulment in pursuance of aresolution of the National Assembly for Wales.
			Regulations made under this section by the Department of Education—
				are a statutory rule for the purposes of the Statutory Rules (NorthernIreland) Order 1979 ([S.I. 1979/1573 (N.I. 12)](/id/nisi/1979/1573?view=plain"Go to item of legislation")), and
				are subject to negative resolution within the meaning of section 41(6) ofthe Interpretation Act (Northern Ireland) [1954 (c. 33(N.I.))](/id/apni/1954/33?view=plain "Go to item of legislation").
		Gifts of medical supplies and equipment
			This section applies if—
				a company carrying on a trade makes a gift from trading stock of medicalsupplies or medical equipment,
				it makes the gift for humanitarian purposes, and
				the supplies or equipment are for human use.
			In calculating the profits of the trade, no amount is required to bebrought into account as a receipt in consequence of the gift.
			In calculating the profits of the trade, a deduction is allowed for anycosts of transportation, delivery or distribution incurred by the company inmaking the gift.
			The deduction is allowed for the accounting period in which the costs areincurred.
			The Treasury may by order provide that this section is not to have effectin relation to medical supplies or medical equipment of any descriptionspecified in the order.
			This section needs to be read with section 108 (receipt of benefits bydonor or connected person).
	Benefits associated with gifts
		Receipt of benefits by donor or connected person
			This section applies if a company carrying on a trade makes a gift inrelation to which relief is given under—
				section 105,
				section 107(2), or
				section 63(2) of CAA 2001 (gifts to charities etc of plant or machineryused in the trade),
					and the company, or a person connected with the company, receives a benefitwhich is in any way attributable to the making of the gift.
			This section also applies if—
				relief is given under section 107(3) for costs of transportation, deliveryor distribution incurred by a company carrying on a trade, and
				the company, or a person connected with the company, receives a benefitwhich is in any way attributable to the company’s incurring of those costs.
			An amount equal to the value of the benefit—
				is brought into account in calculating the profits of the trade, as areceipt of the trade arising in the accounting period in which the benefit isreceived, or
				if the company has permanently ceased to carry on the trade before thebenefit is received, is treated as a post-cessation receipt (see Chapter 15).

Introduction
	Election for application of herd basis rules
		A company, or a firm of which a company is a member, which keeps or haskept a production herd for the purposes of a trade may make an election underthis Chapter (a “herd basis election”).
		In calculating the profits of the trade, animals which are part of aproduction herd in relation to which a herd basis election has effect—
			are not treated as trading stock (see section 50), but
			are treated instead in accordance with sections 112 to 121 (“the herd basisrules”).
		This Chapter is expressed in terms of farmers but applies to any company,or firm of which a company is a member, which keeps or has kept a productionherd for the purposes of a trade, whether or not the trade is farming.
		References in this Chapter to keeping a production herd are to keeping itfor the purposes of the trade.
	Meaning of “animal”, “herd”, “production herd” etc
		In this Chapter—
			“animal” means any animal or other living creature,
			“herd” includes a flock and any other collection of animals (howevernamed), and
			“production herd” means, in relation to a farmer, a herd of animals of thesame species (irrespective of breed) kept by the farmer wholly or mainly forthe products obtainable from the living animal which the animals produce forthe farmer to sell.
		For this purpose “the products obtainable from the living animal” means—
			the young of the animal, or
			any other product obtainable from the animal without slaughtering it.
		For the purposes of this Chapter the general rule is that immature animalskept in a production herd are not part of the herd.
		There is an exception to this rule if—
			the nature of the land on which the herd is kept means that animals whichdie or cease to be part of the herd can be replaced only by animals bred andreared on the land,
			the immature animals in question are bred in the herd and are maintained inthe herd for the purpose of replacing other animals, and
			it is necessary to maintain the immature animals for that purpose.
		In that case the immature animals are part of the herd for the purposes ofthis Chapter, but only so far as they are required to prevent a fall in thenumbers of the herd.
		References in this Chapter to an animal being added to a herd includereferences to an immature animal that is not part of the herd reachingmaturity.
		This Chapter applies—
			in relation to animals kept singly as it applies in relation to herds, and
			in relation to shares in animals as it applies in relation to animalsthemselves.
	Other interpretative provisions
		This section applies for the purposes of this Chapter.
		A production herd kept by a farmer is of the same class as anotherproduction herd only if—
			the animals kept in both herds are of the same species (irrespective ofbreed), and
			the products produced for the farmer to sell (for which the herds arewholly or mainly kept) are of the same kinds in both herds.
		References to the sale of an animal include references to its death ordestruction.
		References to the sale proceeds of an animal include references to—
			money received from an insurer because of the animal’s death ordestruction,
			compensation money received because of the animal’s death or destruction,and
			the sale proceeds of the animal’s carcass or any part of its carcass.
		Female animals become mature—
			in the case of laying birds, when they first lay, and
			in any other case, when they produce their first young.
		20% or more of a herd is a substantial part of the herd, but a lesserpercentage than 20% is capable of being a substantial part of the herddepending on the circumstances of the case concerned.

The herd basis rules
	Initial cost of herd and value of herd
		In calculating the profits of the trade, no deduction is allowed for theinitial cost of the herd.
		In calculating the profits of the trade, the value of the herd is notbrought into account.
	Addition of animals to herd
		This section applies for the purpose of calculating the profits of thetrade if an animal is added to the herd, unless it replaces another animal inthe herd.
		No deduction is allowed for the cost of the animal.
		If, immediately before it was added to the herd, the animal was part of thefarmer’s trading stock, the balancing amount is brought into account as areceipt.
		“The balancing amount” means—
			in the case of an animal bred by the farmer, the cost of breeding theanimal and rearing it to maturity, and
			in any other case, the sum of the initial cost of acquiring the animal andthe cost (if any) incurred by the farmer in rearing the animal to maturity.
	Replacement of animals in herd
		This section applies for the purpose of calculating the profits of thetrade if—
			an animal (“the old animal”) is sold from the herd or otherwise ceases tobe part of the herd, and
			it is replaced in the herd by another animal (“the new animal”).
		The sale proceeds (if any) of the old animal are brought into account as areceipt.
		But this needs to be read with—
			section 115 (amount of receipt if old animal slaughtered under diseasecontrol order),
			section 118 (acquisition of new herd begun within 5 years of sale), and
			section 120 (replacement of part sold begun within 5 years of sale).
		Except so far as otherwise allowable, a deduction is allowed under thissection for the cost of the new animal.
		But if the new animal is of better quality than the old animal, the amountof the deduction must not exceed the amount that it would have been necessaryto spend to replace the old animal with an animal of the same quality.
	Amount of receipt if old animal slaughtered under disease controlorder
		This section applies for the purposes of section 114.
		If— 
			the old animal was slaughtered under a disease control order, and
			the new animal is of worse quality than the old animal,
				the amount brought into account as a receipt under section 114 must not exceedthe equivalent amount for the new animal.
		For this purpose “a disease control order” means an order made under thelaw relating to the diseases of animals by—
			central government,
			a devolved authority,
			a local authority, or
			another public authority.
		If, immediately before it was added to the herd, the new animal was part ofthe farmer’s trading stock, “the equivalent amount for the new animal” means—
			in the case of an animal bred by the farmer, the cost of breeding theanimal and rearing it to maturity, and
			in any other case, the sum of the initial cost of acquiring the animal andthe cost (if any) incurred by the farmer in rearing the animal to maturity.
		Otherwise “the equivalent amount for the new animal” means the cost of thenew animal.
	Sale of animals from herd
		This section applies for the purpose of calculating the profits of thetrade if an animal is sold from the herd unless—
			it is replaced in the herd by another animal (see section 114), or
			it is sold as part of the sale of the whole or a substantial part of theherd that takes place all at once or over a period not longer than 12 months(see section 117).
		A profit arising from the sale is brought into account as a receipt.
		A deduction is allowed for a loss arising from the sale.
		The amount of the profit or loss is the difference between the saleproceeds of the animal and the deductible amount for the animal.
		“The deductible amount for the animal” means—
			in the case of an animal bred by the farmer, the cost of breeding theanimal and rearing it to maturity,
			in the case of an animal acquired by the farmer for valuable consideration,the sum of the initial cost to the farmer of acquiring the animal and the cost(if any) incurred by the farmer in rearing the animal to maturity, and
			in the case of an animal acquired by the farmer but not for valuableconsideration, the sum of the market value of the animal when acquired and thecost (if any) incurred by the farmer in rearing the animal to maturity.
	Sale of whole or substantial part of herd
		This section applies for the purpose of calculating the profits of thetrade if, either all at once or over a period not longer than 12 months, theherd or a substantial part of the herd is sold unless—
			section 118 applies (acquisition of new herd begun within 5 years of sale),or
			section 120 applies (replacement of part sold begun within 5 years ofsale),
				but paragraph (a) is subject to subsection (5) of section 118 (so far as thatsection provides for a case in which this section is to apply).
		A profit arising from the sale is not brought into account as a receipt.
		No deduction is allowed for a loss arising from the sale.
	Acquisition of new herd begun within 5 years of sale
		This section applies for the purpose of calculating the profits of thetrade if—
			either all at once or over a period not longer than 12 months, the herd(“the old herd”) is sold, and
			the farmer acquires or starts to acquire another production herd of thesame class (“the new herd”) within 5 years of the sale.
		Section 114 (replacement of animals in herd) applies as if a number ofanimals equal to—
			the number of animals in the old herd, or
			if smaller, the number of animals in the new herd,
				had been sold from the old herd and replaced in that herd (but see section 119(sale for reasons outside farmer’s control)).
		For the purposes of section 114, the sale proceeds of an animal that istreated as a result of subsection (2) above as if it had been—
			sold from the old herd, and
			replaced in that herd by another animal (“the new animal”),
			are not brought into account as a receipt until the new animal is acquired.
		If— 
			the number of animals in the new herd is smaller than the number of animalsin the old herd, and
			the difference is not substantial,
			section 116 (sale of animals from herd) applies as if a number of animalsequal to the difference had been sold from the old herd.
		If the number of animals in the new herd is smaller than the number ofanimals in the old herd and the difference is substantial—
			section 117 (sale of whole or substantial part of herd where replacementnot begun within 5 years), or
			section 120 (sale of substantial part of herd where replacement begunwithin 5 years),
			applies as if a number of animals equal to the difference had been sold fromthe old herd.
		If the number of animals in the new herd is larger than the number ofanimals in the old herd, section 113 (addition of animals to herd) applies asif a number of animals equal to the difference had been added to the old herd.
		For the purposes of this section—
			if the difference between the number of animals in the new herd and thenumber of animals in the old herd is equal to 20% or more of the number ofanimals in the old herd, the difference is substantial, but
			a lesser percentage than 20% is capable of being a substantial differencedepending on the circumstances of the case concerned.
	Section 118: sale for reasons outside farmer’s control
		This section applies for the purposes of section 114, as applied by section118(2).
		If— 
			the farmer was compelled to sell the old herd for reasons wholly outsidethe farmer’s control, and
			an animal (“the new animal”) that is treated as a result of section 118(2)as if it replaced an animal sold (“the old animal”) is of worse quality thanthe old animal,
				the amount brought into account as a receipt under section 114 must not exceedthe equivalent amount for the new animal.
		If, immediately before it was added to the herd, the new animal was part ofthe farmer’s trading stock, “the equivalent amount for the new animal” means—
			in the case of an animal bred by the farmer, the cost of breeding theanimal and rearing it to maturity, and
			in any other case, the sum of the initial cost of acquiring the animal andthe cost (if any) incurred by the farmer in rearing the animal to maturity.
		Otherwise “the equivalent amount for the new animal” means the cost of thenew animal.
	Replacement of part sold begun within 5 years of sale
		This section applies for the purpose of calculating the profits of thetrade if—
			either all at once or over a period not longer than 12 months, asubstantial part of the herd is sold, and
			the farmer acquires or starts to acquire animals to replace the part soldwithin 5 years of the sale.
		Section 114 (replacement of animals in herd) applies so far as the animalsincluded in the part sold are replaced (but see section 121 (sale for reasonsoutside farmer’s control)).
		The sale proceeds of an animal included in the part sold are not broughtinto account as a receipt until the animal that replaces it in the herd isacquired.
		If some of the animals included in the part sold are not replaced—
			a profit arising from their sale is not brought into account as a receipt,and
			no deduction is allowed for a loss arising from their sale.
	Section 120: sale for reasons outside farmer’s control
		This section applies for the purposes of section 114, as applied by section120(2).
		If— 
			the farmer was compelled to sell the part of the herd for reasons whollyoutside the farmer’s control, and
			an animal (“the new animal”) that replaces an animal sold (“the oldanimal”) is of worse quality than the old animal,
				the amount brought into account as a receipt under section 114 must not exceedthe equivalent amount for the new animal.
		If, immediately before it was added to the herd, the new animal was part ofthe farmer’s trading stock, “the equivalent amount for the new animal” means—
			in the case of an animal bred by the farmer, the cost of breeding theanimal and rearing it to maturity, and
			in any other case, the sum of the initial cost of acquiring the animal andthe cost (if any) incurred by the farmer in rearing the animal to maturity.
		Otherwise “the equivalent amount for the new animal” means the cost of thenew animal.

Elections
	Herd basis elections
		A herd basis election must specify the class of production herd to which itrelates.
		A herd basis election must be made—
			not later than two years after the end of the first relevant accountingperiod (if the farmer is not a firm), or
			on or before the first anniversary of the normal self-assessment filingdate for the tax year in which the first relevant period of account ends (ifthe farmer is a firm).
		For this purpose—
			“the first relevant accounting period” means the first accounting period inwhich the farmer making the election keeps a production herd of the class towhich the election relates, and
			“the first relevant period of account” means the first period of account inwhich the firm making the election keeps a production herd of the class towhich the election relates (but see subsection (8)).
		A herd basis election cannot relate to more than one class of productionherd, but separate elections may be made for different classes.
		A herd basis election is irrevocable.
		A herd basis election has effect in relation to all production herds of theclass to which it relates, including any which the farmer—
			has ceased to keep before making the election, or
			first keeps after making the election.
		A herd basis election has effect—
			for every accounting period in which the farmer carries on the trade andkeeps a production herd of the class to which the election relates (if thefarmer is not a firm), or
			for every period of account in which the farmer carries on the trade andkeeps a production herd of the class to which the election relates (if thefarmer is a firm).
		If the farmer is a firm and there is a change in the persons who arepartners in the firm—
			any herd basis election made by the old firm ceases to have effect, and
			in relation to the new firm, “the first relevant period of account” meansthe first period of account in which the new firm keeps a production herd ofthe class to which the election relates.
	Five year gap in which no production herd kept
		This section applies if a farmer—
			keeps a production herd of a particular class, and
			ceases altogether to keep herds of that class for a period of at least 5years.
		If the farmer keeps a production herd of that class after the end of thatperiod—
			the accounting period or (as the case may be) period of account in whichthe farmer starts to keep the herd is treated as the first accounting periodor period of account in which the farmer keeps a production herd of thatclass, and
			any herd basis election previously made by the farmer in relation toproduction herds of that class ceases to have effect.
	Slaughter under disease control order
		This section applies if—
			the whole or a substantial part of a production herd kept by a farmer isslaughtered under a disease control order, and
			the circumstances of the slaughter are such that compensation is payable inrespect of the animals slaughtered.
		The farmer may make a herd basis election in respect of the class ofproduction herd involved in the slaughter as if the accounting period or (asthe case may be) period of account —
			in which the compensation falls to be brought into account in calculatingthe profits of the trade, or
			in which it would (but for the election) fall to be so brought intoaccount,
				were the first accounting period or period of account in which the farmerkeeps a production herd of that class.
		An election made as a result of this section has effect for that accountingperiod or period of account and every subsequent accounting period or periodof account in which the farmer—
			carries on the trade, and
			keeps a production herd of the class to which the election relates.
		In this section “disease control order” means an order made under the lawrelating to the diseases of animals by—
			central government,
			a devolved authority,
			a local authority, or
			another public authority.

Preventing abuse of the herd basis rules
	Preventing abuse of the herd basis rules
		This section applies if—
			a person carrying on a trade (the “transferor”) transfers the whole or partof a production herd to another person (the “transferee”),
			the transfer is not by way of sale or is by way of sale but for a priceother than that which the animals sold would have fetched if sold in the openmarket, and
			the control condition or herd basis benefit condition is met.
		The control condition is met if—
			the transferor is a body of persons over which the transferee has control,
			the transferee is a body of persons over which the transferor has control,or
			both the transferor and transferee are bodies of persons and another personhas control over both of them.
		For this purpose “body of persons” includes a firm.
		The herd basis benefit condition is met if—
			the transferor or transferee (or both) might (but for this section) havebeen expected to obtain a herd basis benefit as a result of the transfer orthe transactions of which the transfer is one, and
			the herd basis benefit is the sole or main benefit, or one of the mainbenefits, that the person in question might have been expected to obtain.
		For this purpose a “herd basis benefit” is a benefit resulting from—
			the obtaining of a right to make a herd basis election,
			the herd basis rules applying or not applying, or
			the herd basis rules having a greater or lesser effect.
		For the purpose of calculating the profits of—
			the trade carried on by the transferor, and
			any trade carried on by the transferee,
				the animals transferred are treated as having been sold at the price whichthey would have fetched if sold in the open market.

Supplementary
	Information if election made
		An officer of Revenue and Customs may by notice require the person carryingon a trade in relation to which a herd basis election is made to deliver areturn of such information about—
			the animals kept for the purposes of the trade, and
			the products of those animals,
				as may be required by the notice.
		The return must be delivered to an officer of Revenue and Customs withinthe time specified in the notice.
	Further assessment etc if herd basis rules apply
		If the herd basis rules apply in calculating the profits of an accountingperiod after an assessment for that period has become final and conclusive,any assessment or repayment of tax that is necessary to give effect to therules must be made.
		But repayment of tax is due only if a claim for it is made.

Dealers in securities etc
	Taxation of amounts taken to reserves
		This section applies for the purpose of calculating the profits of acompany’s trade if—
			the company carries on a banking business, an insurance business or abusiness consisting wholly or partly of dealing in securities, and
			a profit on the sale of securities held by the company would be broughtinto account in calculating the trading profits of that business.
		Profits and losses from the securities that in accordance with generallyaccepted accounting practice are—
			calculated by reference to the fair value of the securities, and
			recognised in the company’s statement of recognised gains and losses orstatement of changes in equity,
				are brought into account in calculating the profits of the trade.
		But subsection (2) does not apply—
			to an amount so far as deriving from or otherwise relating to an amountbrought into account under that subsection in an earlier period of account, or
			to an amount recognised for accounting purposes by way of correction of afundamental error.
		In this section “securities” includes—
			shares, 
			rights of unit holders in unit trust schemes to which TCGA 1992 applies asa result of section 99 of TCGA 1992, and
			in the case of a company with no share capital, interests in the companypossessed by members of the company,
			but does not include a loan relationship (within the meaning of Part 5).
	Conversion etc of securities held as circulating capital
		This section applies for the purpose of calculating the profits of acompany’s trade if—
			the company carries on a banking business, an insurance business or abusiness consisting wholly or partly of dealing in securities,
			a transaction falling within subsection (2) occurs in relation tosecurities (“the original holding”), and
			a profit on the sale of the securities would be brought into account incalculating the trading profits of that business.
		A transaction falls within this subsection if—
			it results in a new holding being treated as the same as the originalholding as a result of sections 126 to 136 of TCGA 1992 (roll-over relief incases of conversion etc), or
			it is treated, as a result of section 134 of TCGA 1992 (compensationstock), as an exchange for a new holding which does not involve a disposal ofthe original holding.
		This section does not apply to securities in respect of which unrealisedprofits or losses, calculated by reference to the fair value of the securitiesat the end of the period of account, are taken into account in the period ofaccount in which the transaction occurs.
		The transaction is treated as not involving a disposal of the originalholding and the new holding is treated as the same asset as the originalholding.
		But if, under the transaction, the company carrying on the trade—
			receives consideration in addition to the new holding, or
			becomes entitled to receive such consideration,
				subsection (4) applies as if the references to the original holding were tothe proportion of the original holding given by the following fraction.
		The fraction is—
		[![](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_007)](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_007?view=plain)
		where—
			  * NH is the market value of the new holding at the time of the transaction, and 
			  * C is the market value of the consideration at the time of the transaction or (if the consideration is cash) the amount of the consideration. 
		In determining whether subsection (2)(a) applies as a result of section 135or 136 of TCGA 1992, the reference to capital gains tax in section 137(1) ofTCGA 1992 is to be read as a reference to income tax.
		In this section “securities” includes—
			shares, 
			rights of unit holders in unit trust schemes to which TCGA 1992 applies asa result of section 99 of TCGA 1992, and
			in the case of a company with no share capital, interests in the companypossessed by members of the company.
	Traders receiving distributions etc
		A receipt of a trade which is—
			a UK distribution, or
			a payment representative of a UK distribution,
				is brought into account in calculating the profits of the trade.
		Subsection (1) is an exception to section 1285(2) (under which UK companydistributions are not generally taken into account in calculating income).
		Subsection (4) applies if—
			a payment made by a company carrying on a trade is representative of a UKdistribution, and
			but for section 1305(1) (company’s profits to be computed without anydeduction for distributions), a deduction would be allowed for the payment incalculating the profits of the trade.
		A deduction is allowed for the payment in calculating the profits of thetrade (despite section 1305(1)).
		Subsections (1) to (4) do not apply to receipts, or payments, in the courseof insurance business or any category of insurance business.
		In this section “UK distribution” means a distribution made by a UKresident company.

Building societies
	Incidental costs of issuing qualifying shares
		In calculating the profits of a trade carried on by a building society, adeduction is allowed for incidental costs of obtaining finance by means ofissuing shares in the society if—
			the shares are qualifying shares for the purposes of section 117(4) of TCGA1992, and
			the condition in subsection (2) is met.
		The condition is that the amount of any—
			dividend or other distribution, or
			interest, 
				payable in respect of the shares is deductible in calculating, for corporationtax purposes, the profits of the society’s trade.
		But a deduction is not allowed by virtue of subsection (1) so far as thecosts fall to be brought into account as debits for the purposes of Part 5(loan relationships).
		“Incidental costs of obtaining finance” means expenses—
			which are incurred on fees, commissions, advertising, printing and otherincidental matters, and
			which are incurred wholly and exclusively for the purpose of obtaining thefinance, providing security for it or repaying it.
		Expenses incurred wholly and exclusively for the purpose of—
			obtaining finance, or
			providing security for it,
			are incidental costs of obtaining the finance even if it is not in factobtained.
		But the following are not incidental costs of obtaining finance—
			sums paid because of losses resulting from movements in the rate ofexchange between different currencies,
			sums paid for the purpose of protecting against such losses,
			the cost of repaying qualifying shares so far as attributable to theirbeing repayable at a premium or having been issued at a discount, and
			stamp duty.

Industrial and provident societies
	Dividends etc granted by industrial and provident societies
		This section applies if a trade is carried on by a registered industrialand provident society and—
			the society does not sell to persons who are not its members, or
			the number of shares in the society is not limited by the society’s rulesor practice.
		In calculating the profits of the trade, a deduction is allowed for sumswhich meet conditions A and B.
		Condition A is that—
			the sum represents a discount, rebate, dividend or bonus granted by thesociety to a member or other person (“the recipient”),
			the discount, rebate, dividend or bonus is in respect of—
			amounts paid or payable by the recipient, or
			amounts paid or payable to the recipient,
				on account of the recipient’s transactions with the society, and
			those transactions are taken into account in calculating the society’sprofits chargeable under this Part.
		Condition B is that the sum mentioned in subsection (2) is calculated byreference to—
			the amounts paid or payable by or to the recipient, or
			the size of the transactions,
			and not by reference to the amount of any share or interest in the capital ofthe society.
		See also section 230A of ICTA (dividend or bonus to which this sectionapplies is not treated as a distribution).

Dealers in land etc
	Purchase or sale of woodlands
		This section applies for the purpose of calculating the profits of a tradeof dealing in land.
		If the company carrying on the trade buys woodlands in the United Kingdomin the course of the trade, the part of the cost of the woodlands which isattributable to trees or saleable underwood growing on the land is ignored.
		If— 
			the woodlands are subsequently sold in the course of the trade, and
			any of the trees or underwood are still growing on the land at the time ofthe sale,
				the part of the price that is equal to the amount ignored under subsection (2)for those trees or that underwood is ignored.
	Relief in respect of mineral royalties
		This section applies for the purpose of calculating the profits of a tradecarried on by a UK resident company in an accounting period if the receipts ofthe trade include mineral royalties—
			which the company is entitled to receive under a mineral lease oragreement, and
			which are not chargeable to tax under Chapter 7 of Part 4 (rent receivablein connection with a UK section 39(4) concern) because of the priority rule insection 287.
		The company is treated as entitled to receive only half of the total of themineral royalties arising under the lease or agreement in the accountingperiod.
		Sections 274 to 276 (meaning of “mineral lease or agreement” and “mineralroyalties”) apply for the purposes of this section as they apply for thepurposes of Chapter 7 of Part 4.
		See also section 201 of TCGA 1992 (gains treated as accruing to a companyentitled to receive mineral royalties).
	Lease premiums etc: reduction of receipts
		This section applies for the purpose of calculating the profits of a tradeof dealing in land if a receipt of the trade falls within one of the followingcategories—
			lease premiums within section 217,
			sums within section 219 (sums payable instead of rent),
			sums within section 220 (sums payable for surrender of a lease),
			sums within section 221 (sums payable for variation or waiver of terms oflease),
			consideration for the assignment of a lease within section 222 (leasegranted at an undervalue), and
			amounts received on the sale of an estate or interest in land withinsection 224 (sales with right to reconveyance) or section 225 (sale andleaseback transactions).
		The receipt is reduced by the relevant amount.
		The relevant amount is the amount which is treated as a receipt of aproperty business as a result of any of sections 217 to 225.
		But if—
			the company carrying on the trade makes a claim under section 238 or 239,and
			as a result of the claim a repayment of tax is made to that company,
				the relevant amount is the amount which, for the purpose of determining theamount of the repayment of tax, is treated as brought into account as areceipt in calculating the profits of the property business.
		If subsection (4) applies, any adjustment of liability to tax may be made—
			by assessment or otherwise, and
			at any time at which it could be made if it related only to tax for theaccounting period in which the claim under section 238 or 239 is made.

Mineral exploration and access
	Mineral exploration and access
		This section applies for the purpose of calculating the profits of a tradeif—
			the company carrying on the trade incurs expenditure on mineral explorationand access in an area or group of sands, and
			the presence of mineral deposits in commercial quantities has already beenestablished in that area or group of sands.
		A deduction is allowed for the expenditure only if a deduction would havebeen allowed for it if the presence of mineral deposits in commercialquantities had not already been established in that area or group of sands.
		In this section “mineral exploration and access” has the same meaning as inPart 5 of CAA 2001 (see section 396(1) of that Act).

Companies liable to pool betting duty
	Payments by companies liable to pool betting duty
		This section applies for the purpose of calculating the profits of a tradeif—
			the company carrying on the trade is liable to pool betting duty,
			there is a reduction in that duty, and
			the company makes a qualifying payment in consequence of that reduction.
		A qualifying payment is one—
			made in order to meet (directly or indirectly) capital expenditure incurredby any person in improving the safety or comfort of spectators at a ground tobe used for the playing of association football, or
			made to trustees established mainly for the support of athletic sports orathletic games but with power to support the arts.
		A deduction is allowed for the qualifying payment.

Intermediaries treated as making employment payments
	Deduction for deemed employment payment
		This section applies for the purpose of calculating the profits of a tradecarried on by an intermediary which is treated as making a deemed employmentpayment in connection with the trade.
		A deduction is allowed for—
			the amount of the deemed employment payment, and
			the amount of any employer’s national insurance contributions paid by theintermediary in respect of it.
		The deduction is allowed for the period of account in which the deemedemployment payment is treated as made.
		No deduction in respect of—
			the deemed employment payment, or
			any employer’s national insurance contributions paid by the intermediary inrespect of it,
				may be made except in accordance with this section.
		In this section “deemed employment payment” and “intermediary” have thesame meaning as in Chapter 8 of Part 2 of ITEPA 2003 (see sections 49 and 50of that Act).
	Special rules for partnerships
		This section applies for the purpose of calculating the profits of a tradecarried on by a firm that is treated as making a deemed employment payment inconnection with the trade.
		The amount of the deduction allowed under section 139 is limited to theamount that reduces the profits of the firm of the period of account to nil.
		The expenses of the firm in connection with the relevant engagements forany period of account are limited to the total of—
			5% of the amount taken into account at Step 1 of the calculation in section54(1) of ITEPA 2003 (calculation of deemed employment payment), and
			the amount deductible at Step 3 of that calculation.
		In this section “deemed employment payment” and “the relevant engagements”have the same meaning as in Chapter 8 of Part 2 of ITEPA 2003 (see sections 49and 50 of that Act).

Managed service companies
	Deduction for deemed employment payments
		This section applies for the purpose of calculating the profits of a tradecarried on by a managed service company (the “MSC”) which is treated as makinga deemed employment payment in connection with the trade.
		A deduction is allowed for—
			the amount of the deemed employment payment, and
			the amount of any employer’s national insurance contributions paid by theMSC in respect of it.
		The deduction is allowed for the period of account in which the deemedemployment payment is treated as made.
		If the MSC is a firm, the amount of the deduction allowed under subsection(2) is limited to the amount that reduces the profits of the firm of theperiod of account to nil.
		No deduction in respect of—
			the deemed employment payment, or
			any employer’s national insurance contributions paid by the MSC in respectof it,
				may be made except in accordance with this section.
		In this section the following expressions have the same meanings as inChapter 9 of Part 2 of ITEPA 2003—
			  * “deemed employment payment” (see section 61D(2) of that Act), 
			  * “employer’s national insurance contributions” (see section 61J(1) of that Act), 
			  * “managed service company” (see section 61B of that Act).

Waste disposal
	Deduction for site preparation expenditure
		This section applies for the purpose of calculating the profits of a tradeof a period of account in which waste materials are deposited on a wastedisposal site if—
			the company carrying on the trade (“the trader”), or a predecessor, hasincurred site preparation expenditure in relation to the site in the course ofcarrying on the trade, and
			at the time the trader first deposits waste materials on the site, thetrader holds a waste disposal licence which is then in force.
		A deduction is allowed for the amount of the site preparation expenditureallocated to the period of account under section 143.
		For the purposes of this section “predecessor”, in relation to the trader,means a person who—
			has ceased to carry on the trade carried on by the trader or ceased tocarry on a trade so far as relating to the site, and
			has transferred the whole of the site to the trader,
				and it does not matter for this purpose whether or not the estate or interestin the site transferred to the trader is the same as that held by that person.
		For the purposes of this section and section 143, if site preparationexpenditure has been incurred by a predecessor—
			the trade carried on by the trader is treated as the same as the tradecarried on by the predecessor, and
			deductions are to be allowed to the trader (and not to the predecessor) asif everything done to or by the predecessor were done to or by the trader.
		For— 
			the meaning of “site preparation expenditure”, “waste disposal licence” and“waste disposal site”, and
			a rule about pre-trading expenditure,
			see section 144.
	Allocation of site preparation expenditure
		The amount of site preparation expenditure allocated to a period of accountfor the purposes of section 142(2) is the amount given by the formula—
			[![](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_008)](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_008?view=plain)
		where—
			  * RE means residual expenditure (see subsection (2)), 
			  * WD means the volume of waste materials deposited on the waste disposal site during the period, and 
			  * SV means the volume of the waste disposal site not used up for the deposit of waste materials at the end of the period. 
		“Residual expenditure” means the total of all site preparation expenditureincurred by the trader in relation to the waste disposal site at any timebefore the end of the period, less—
			any of that expenditure for which an allowance has been, or may be, madefor corporation or income tax purposes under the enactments relating tocapital allowances,
			any of that expenditure for which a deduction has been made in calculatingfor corporation or income tax purposes the profits of an earlier period ofaccount, and

		The excluded amount of unrelieved old expenditure is calculated bymultiplying the unrelieved old expenditure (see subsection (4)) by thefraction—

			was incurred by the trader in relation to the waste disposal site before 6April 1989, and
