				  * “receiver” means a person appointed as receiver of some or all of the property of the company or firm under an enactment or under an instrument issued for the purpose of representing security for, or the rights of creditors in respect of, any debt. 
			For the meaning of “control”, “major interest”, “associate”,“participator”, see sections 836, 837 and 841.
		“Control” 
			For the purposes of this Chapter, in relation to a company, “control” meansthe power of a person to secure that the company’s affairs are conducted inaccordance with the person’s wishes—
				by means of the holding of shares or the possession of voting power in orin relation to the company or any other company, or
				as a result of powers conferred by the articles of association or otherdocument regulating the company or any other company.
			Sections 838 to 840 (rights and powers to be taken into account) apply inrelation to the determination for the purposes of this Chapter whether aperson has control of a company.
		“Major interest”
			For the purposes of this Chapter, a person has a “major interest” in acompany if—
				the person and one other person together have control of that company, and
				the rights and powers by means of which they have such control represent,in the case of each of them, at least 40% of the total.
			The reference in subsection (1)(a) to two persons together having controlof a company is to two persons who, taken together, have the power mentionedin section 836.
			Sections 838 to 840 (rights and powers to be taken into account) apply inrelation to the determination for the purposes of this Chapter whether aperson has a major interest in a company.
	Rights and powers to be taken into account
		General rule
			This section provides for a person (“A”) to be treated as having rights andpowers where A’s rights or powers are relevant in determining if a person—
				has control of a company, or
				has a major interest in a company.
			A is treated as having rights and powers that A—
				is entitled to acquire at a future date, or
				will, at a future date, become entitled to acquire.
			A is treated as having rights and powers of other persons, so far as theyare required or may be required to be exercised in any one or more of thefollowing ways—
				on A’s behalf,
				under A’s direction, or
				for A’s benefit.
			A is treated as having rights and powers of a person connected with A (seesection 842).
			A is treated as having rights and powers that a person connected with Awould be treated as having if that person were a person whose rights or powersare relevant in determining if a person has control of or a major interest ina company.
			For the purposes of subsections (3) to (5), a person is treated as havingrights or powers that the person—
				is entitled to acquire at a future date, or
				will, at a future date, become entitled to acquire.
			Subsection (3) does not apply to rights and powers conferred in relation toproperty of a borrower by the terms of any security relating to the borrower’sloan.
		Rights and powers held jointly
			References in this Chapter—
				to rights and powers of a person, or
				to rights and powers that a person is or will become entitled to acquire,
					include rights or powers that are exercisable by that person, or when acquiredwill be exercisable by that person, only jointly with one or more otherpersons.
			Subsection (1) is subject to section 840 (partnerships).
		Partnerships 
			The rights and powers of a person as a member of a firm are ignored unlessthe person has control of or a major interest in the firm.
			Whether a person has control of or a major interest in a firm is determinedin accordance with sections 836 to 839 as in relation to a company.
			For the purposes of subsection (2), references in those sections to anyother company must be read as including any other firm.
	Meaning of “participator” and “associate”
		“Participator” and “associate”
			In this Chapter “participator”, in relation to a close company, has themeaning it has for the purposes of Part 11 of ICTA (close companies) (seesection 417(1) of that Act), except as provided in subsection (2).
			“Participator” does not include a person just because the person is a loancreditor of the company within the meaning of that Part (see section 417(7) to(9) of ICTA).
			In this Chapter “associate”, in relation to a participator in a closecompany, has the meaning given by section 417(3) of ICTA.
	Connected persons
		Introduction 
			Section 843 explains what is meant in this Chapter when a person isreferred to as being connected with another person.
			If that section provides that one person (“A”) is connected with anotherperson (“B”), B is connected with A too.
			In that section—
				  * “relative” means brother, sister, ancestor or lineal descendant, and 
				  * “settlement” and “settlor” have the same meaning as in Chapter 5 of Part 5 of ITTOIA (see section 620 of that Act). 
		Who are connected persons
			An individual (“A”) is connected with another individual (“B”) if—
				A is B’s spouse or civil partner,
				A is a relative of B,
				A is the spouse or civil partner of a relative of B,
				A is a relative of B’s spouse or civil partner, or
				A is the spouse or civil partner of a relative of B’s spouse or civilpartner.
			A person in the capacity of a trustee of a settlement is connected with—
				any individual who is a settlor in relation to the settlement,
				any person connected with such an individual, and
				any body corporate that is connected with the settlement.
			For the purposes of subsection (2) a body corporate is connected with asettlement if—
				it is a close company (or not a close company only because it is not UKresident) and the participators include the trustees of the settlement, or
				it is controlled by a company within paragraph (a).
			A person is connected with a company if they are related parties because ofsection 835(2) or (3).
			For the purposes of subsection (4) and for the purposes of section 835 asit applies for the purposes of subsection (4)—
				“company” includes any body corporate or unincorporated association, butdoes not include a firm, and
				a unit trust scheme is treated as if it were a company and as if the rightsof the unit holders were shares in the company.

Chapter 13Transactions between related parties
	Introductory
		Overview of Chapter
			This Chapter sets out special rules relating to transactions betweenrelated parties.
			Sections 845 to 849 are about the rule that transfers between a company anda related party are treated as being at market value.
			Sections 850 and 851 set out other rules for transactions involving relatedparties.
			See Chapter 12 for the meaning of “related parties”.
	Transfers treated as being at market value
		Transfer between company and related party treated as at market value
			The basic rule is that a transfer of an intangible asset—
				from a company to a related party, or
				to a company from a related party,
					is treated for all purposes of the Taxes Acts as being at market value (asrespects both the company and the related party) if condition A or B is met.
			Condition A is that the asset is a chargeable intangible asset in relationto the transferor immediately before the transfer.
			Condition B is that the asset is a chargeable intangible asset in relationto the transferee immediately after the transfer.
			That rule is subject to—
				section 846 (transfers not at arm’s length),
				section 847 (transfers involving other taxes),
				section 848 (tax-neutral transfers), and
				section 849 (transfers involving gifts of business assets).
			In subsection (1)—
				  * “market value” means the price the asset might reasonably be expected to fetch on a sale in the open market, and 
				  * “the Taxes Acts” means the enactments relating to income tax, corporation tax or chargeable gains. 
		Transfers not at arm’s length
			Section 845 does not apply if the consideration for the transfer—
				falls to be adjusted for tax purposes under Schedule 28AA to ICTA(provision not at arm’s length), or
				falls within that Schedule without falling to be so adjusted.
			For the purposes of subsection (1)(b) the consideration for a transferfalls within that Schedule without falling to be adjusted under it if—
				the conditions in paragraph 1(1) of that Schedule are met, but
				the actual provision does not differ from the arm’s length provision.
			In subsection (2) “the actual provision” and “the arm’s length provision”have the same meaning as in that Schedule (see paragraph 1(1) and paragraph1(2) and (3) of that Schedule respectively).
		Transfers involving other taxes
			This section applies if—
				in a case where section 845(1) applies and the asset is transferred fromthe company to a related party, the transfer is at less than its market value,
				in a case where that section applies and the asset is transferred to thecompany from the related party, the transfer is at more than its market value,and
				conditions A and B apply.
			Condition A is that the related party—
				is not a company, or
				is a company in relation to which the asset is not a chargeable intangibleasset immediately after the transfer to it or, as the case may be, immediatelybefore the transfer from it.
			Condition B is that the transfer—
				gives rise to an amount to be taken into account in calculating anyperson’s income, profits or losses for tax purposes because of a relevantprovision, or
				would do so apart from section 845(1).
			If this section applies, section 845(1) does not apply in relation to thecalculation referred to in subsection (3) for the purposes of any relevantprovision.
			In this section “relevant provision” means—
				section 209 of ICTA (meaning of “distribution”), and
				Part 3 of ITEPA 2003 (employment income: earnings and benefits etc treatedas earnings).
		Tax-neutral transfers
			Section 845 does not apply if the transfer is tax-neutral for the purposesof this Part as a result of any provision in this Part.
			For such provisions, see, in particular—
				section 775 (transfers within a group), and
				sections 818 to 826 (transfer of business or trade).
		Transfers involving gifts of business assets
			This section applies if—
				the asset is transferred to the company mentioned in section 845(1), and
				on a claim for relief under section 165 of TCGA 1992 (relief for gifts ofbusiness assets) in respect of the transfer, a reduction is made under section165(4)(a).
			The transfer is treated for the purposes of this Part as being at marketvalue, less the amount of the reduction.
			Any necessary adjustments may be made, by way of assessment, amendment ofreturns or otherwise, regardless of any relevant time limits.
	Other rules
		Part realisation involving related party acquisition: exclusion ofroll-over relief
			Chapter 7 (roll-over relief in case of realisation and reinvestment) doesnot apply in relation to the part realisation by a company of an intangiblefixed asset if there is a related party acquisition as a result of, or inconnection with, the part realisation.
			For this purpose there is a related party acquisition if a person who is arelated party in relation to the company acquires an interest of anydescription—
				in the intangible fixed asset, or
				in an asset whose value is derived in whole or in part from that asset.
		Delayed payment of royalty by company to related party
			This section applies if—
				a royalty is payable by a company to or for the benefit of a related party,
				the royalty is not paid in full within the period of 12 months after theend of the period of account in which a debit in respect of it is recognisedby the company for accounting purposes, and
				credits representing the full amount of the royalty are not brought intoaccount under this Part in any accounting period by the person to whom it ispayable.
			The royalty is brought into account for the purposes of this Part only whenit is paid.

Grants and other contributions to expenditure
	Treatment of grants and other contributions to expenditure
		This section applies if a grant or other payment is intended by the payerto meet, directly or indirectly, expenditure of a company on an intangiblefixed asset.
		A gain recognised in the company’s profit and loss account in respect ofthe grant or other payment is treated for the purposes of section 721(receipts recognised as they accrue) as a gain representing a receipt inrespect of the intangible fixed asset.
		This section does not apply to a grant within section 853.
	Grants to be left out of account for tax purposes
		This section applies to the following grants (“exempt grants”)—
			grants under Part 2 of the Industrial Development Act [1982 (c.52)](/id/ukpga/1982/52?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (regionaldevelopment grants), and
			grants made under Northern Ireland legislation and declared by the Treasuryby order to correspond to a grant under that Part.
		A gain in respect of an exempt grant to a company is ignored for thepurposes of this Part, even though it is recognised in determining thecompany’s profit or loss.
		This subsection applies if, as a result of an exempt grant being broughtinto account by the company to which it is made, there is a reduction—
			in the amount of a loss recognised in determining the company’s profit orloss, or
			in the amount of expenditure on an intangible fixed asset that iscapitalised for accounting purposes.
		If subsection (3) applies, the amount of the reduction is added back forthe purposes of this Part.

Finance leasing
	Finance leasing etc
		The Treasury may make provision by regulations as to the application ofthis Part in relation to a company that is the finance lessor of an intangibleasset that is the subject of a finance lease.
		Section 855 is about the provision that the regulations may make.
		References in this section and that section to a finance lease—
			have the meaning they have for accounting purposes, and
			include hire-purchase, conditional sale or other arrangements if they areof a similar character to a finance lease.
		References to the finance lessor or finance lessee have a correspondingmeaning.
		Regulations under this section may be made so as to have effect from 1April 2002.
	Further provision about regulations under section 854
		Regulations under section 854 may provide that this Part applies as if theasset were an intangible fixed asset of the finance lessor and not a financialasset, even though the asset is accounted for by the finance lessor as afinancial asset.
		The regulations may provide that this Part applies as if the amount atwhich the asset is recognised in the finance lessor’s balance sheet werecapitalised expenditure on an intangible fixed asset, but that—
			no election may be made under section 730 (writing down at fixed rate:election for fixed-rate basis) in respect of that amount, and
			that amount is not to be treated as capitalised expenditure for thepurposes of section 756(2) (roll-over relief in case of realisation andreinvestment: conditions to be met in relation to expenditure on otherassets).
		The regulations may provide that if an asset formerly recognised by thefinance lessor for accounting purposes as an intangible fixed asset becomessubject to a finance lease (and so comes to be accounted for as a financialasset), the value of the asset so created is recognised as realisationproceeds of the intangible fixed asset on the change of accounting treatment.
		The regulations may provide that assets partially excluded from this Partby sections 810 to 813 or section 902 (assets excluded except as respectsroyalties) are entirely excluded from this Part as respects the finance lessorif they—
			are subject to a finance lease, and
			are accounted for by the finance lessor as financial assets.
		The regulations may provide for excluding from the regulations assets usedby the finance lessee for the purposes of a trade or business in respect ofwhich the finance lessee is liable to income tax.
		The regulations may provide that an intangible asset counts as a pre-FA2002 asset in the hands of the finance lessor if the finance lessee is—
			a company for which the asset was the whole or part of a pre-FA 2002 asset,or
			a person who is a related party in relation to such a company.
		The regulations may make incidental, supplemental, consequential andtransitional provision and savings.
		That provision may include modifications of the operation of otherprovisions of the Corporation Tax Acts.

Values to be used in special cases
	Assets acquired or realised together
		Any reference in this Part to the acquisition or realisation of an assetincludes a reference to the acquisition or realisation of that asset togetherwith other assets.
		For the purposes of this Part assets acquired or realised as a result ofone bargain are treated as acquired or realised together even though—
			separate prices are, or purport to be, agreed for separate assets, or
			there are, or purport to be, separate acquisitions or realisations ofseparate assets.
		If assets are acquired together, any values allocated to particular assetsby the company in accordance with generally accepted accounting practice mustbe accepted for the purposes of this Part.
		If no such values are so allocated, so much of the expenditure as on a justand reasonable apportionment is properly attributable to each asset is treatedfor the purposes of this Part as referable to that asset.
		If assets are realised together, so much of the proceeds of realisation ason a just and reasonable apportionment is properly attributable to each assetis treated for the purposes of this Part as proceeds of the realisation ofthat asset.
	Deemed market value acquisition: adjustment where nil accountingvalue
		This section applies if—
			a company is treated for the purposes of this Part as acquiring an asset atmarket value, but
			the accounting value of the asset transferred is nil in the hands of thetransferee.
		In such a case any reference in this Part to—
			the cost of the asset recognised for accounting purposes,
			the accounting value of the asset, or
			any loss recognised for accounting purposes in respect of capitalisedexpenditure on the asset,
				is a reference to the cost, value or loss that would have been recognised ifthe asset had been acquired at market value.
		If the asset is revalued, the revaluation is ignored.
		In this section “revaluation” has the same meaning as in section 723 (seesubsection (5) of that section) and “revalued” must be read accordingly.

Fungible assets
	Fungible assets
		For the purposes of this Part—
			fungible assets of the same kind that are held by the same person in thesame capacity are treated as indistinguishable parts of a single asset,
			that asset is treated as growing as additional assets of the same kind arecreated or acquired, and
			that asset is treated as diminishing as some of the assets are realised.
		In this Part “fungible assets” means assets of a nature to be dealt inwithout identifying the particular assets involved.

Assets ceasing to be or becoming chargeable intangible assets
	Asset ceasing to be chargeable intangible asset: deemed realisationat market value
		If an asset ceases to be a chargeable intangible asset in relation to acompany in any of the circumstances specified in subsection (2), this Partapplies as if—
			immediately before the asset ceased to be a chargeable intangible asset inrelation to the company, the company had realised the asset for its marketvalue at that time, and
			the company had immediately reacquired it at that value.
		The circumstances are—
			that the company ceases to be UK resident,
			in the case of a company that is not UK resident, any circumstances notinvolving the realisation of the asset by the company, and
			that the asset begins to be held for the purposes of a mutual trade orbusiness.
		Subsection (1) is subject to section 860.
	Asset ceasing to be chargeable intangible asset: postponement of gain
		This subsection applies if—
			section 859 applies because a company (“A”) ceases to be UK resident,
			immediately before A ceases to be UK resident the asset is held by it forthe purposes of a trade carried on by it outside the United Kingdom through apermanent establishment,
			the proceeds of the realisation of the asset that is treated as occurringunder section 859 exceed the original cost of the asset recognised for taxpurposes,
			immediately after A ceases to be UK resident it is a 75% subsidiary ofanother company (“B”) that is UK resident, and
			A and B so elect by notice given to an officer of Revenue and Customs notlater than 2 years after the date on which A ceased to be UK resident.
		If subsection (1) applies, this Part applies as if the proceeds of therealisation of the asset that is treated as occurring under section 859 werereduced to the original cost of the asset recognised for tax purposes.
		For the later treatment of the amount of the reduction under subsection(2), see sections 861 and 862.
		In those sections—
			“the postponed gain” means the amount of that reduction, and
			references to “A” and “B” must be read in accordance with this section.
	Treatment of postponed gain on subsequent realisation
		This section applies if A realises the asset to which section 860 appliesbefore the end of the period of 6 years after the date on which it ceases tobe UK resident.
		B must bring into account for tax purposes—
			a credit equal to the postponed gain, or
			in the case of a part realisation, a credit equal to the appropriateproportion of the postponed gain.
		The appropriate proportion is—
			[![](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_039)](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_039?view=plain)
		where—
			  * MVB is the market value of the asset immediately before the part realisation, and 
			  * MVA is the market value of the asset immediately after the part realisation. 
		Subsection (2) does not apply—
			so far as the postponed gain has already been brought into account on aprevious part realisation, or
			if the postponed gain has already been brought into account under section862.
		A credit brought into account by B under this section is treated as a non-trading credit for the purposes of Chapter 6 (how credits and debits are giveneffect).
	Treatment of postponed gain in other cases
		This section applies if at any time after A ceases to be UK resident—
			A ceases to be a 75% subsidiary of B on the disposal by B of ordinaryshares of A,
			A ceases to be such a subsidiary otherwise than on such a disposal andlater B disposes of such shares, or
			B ceases to be UK resident.
		B must bring into account for tax purposes a credit equal to the postponedgain.
		Subsection (2) does not apply so far as the postponed gain has already beenbrought into account under section 861.
		Any credit falling to be brought into account under subsection (2) becauseB ceases to be UK resident must be brought into account immediately before itdoes so.
		A credit brought into account by B under this section is treated as a non-trading credit for the purposes of Chapter 6 (how credits and debits are giveneffect).
	Asset becoming chargeable intangible asset
		This section applies if an asset becomes a chargeable intangible asset inrelation to a company—
			on the company becoming UK resident,
			in the case of a company that is not UK resident, on the asset beginning tobe held for the purposes of a trade carried on by the company in the UnitedKingdom through a permanent establishment, or
			on the asset ceasing to be held for the purposes of a mutual trade orbusiness.
		This Part applies as if—
			the company had acquired the asset immediately after it became a chargeableintangible asset in relation to the company, and
			had done so for its accounting value at that time.

Matters to be ignored
	Tax avoidance arrangements to be ignored
		In determining whether a credit or a debit is to be brought into accountunder this Part and, if so, its amount, any tax avoidance arrangements areignored.
		Arrangements are “tax avoidance arrangements” for this purpose if theirmain object or one of their main objects is to enable a company—
			to obtain a debit under this Part to which it would not otherwise beentitled,
			to obtain a debit under this Part which exceeds that to which it wouldotherwise be entitled,
			to avoid having to bring a credit into account under this Part, or
			to reduce the amount of any such credit.
		In this section—
			  * “arrangements” includes any scheme, agreement or understanding, whether or not it is legally enforceable, and 
			  * “brought into account” means brought into account for tax purposes. 
	Debits for expenditure not generally deductible for tax purposes
		No debit may be brought into account for tax purposes under this Part inrespect of expenditure that is not generally deductible for tax purposes.
		Expenditure is “not generally deductible for tax purposes” so far asrevenue expenditure of that description incurred for the purposes of a tradewould be non-deductible because of a provision specified in subsection (3).
		Those provisions are—
			section 56 (car or motor cycle hire),
			section 1298 (business entertainment and gifts),
			section 1304 (crime-related payments), and
			section 246(2) of FA 2004 (expenditure on benefits under employer-financedretirement benefits schemes).

Delayed payments and bad debts
	Delayed payment of employees' remuneration
		This subsection applies if—
			a debit in respect of employees' remuneration is recognised by a companyfor accounting purposes, and
			apart from this section, a debit in respect of the remuneration could bebrought into account for the purposes of this Part for the period of accountin which the debit is recognised.
		No such debit may be so brought into account unless the remuneration ispaid before the end of the period of 9 months beginning with the end of theperiod of account.
		If the remuneration is paid after the end of the 9 month period, the debitmay be brought into account for the purposes of this Part for the period ofaccount in which it is paid.
		Section 867 makes further provision relating to the application of thissection.
	Provisions supplementing section 866
		For the purposes of section 866 a debit in respect of employees'remuneration recognised for accounting purposes includes an amount reserved inthe accounts of an employer with a view to its becoming employees'remuneration.
		For the purposes of section 866 it does not matter if the debit is inrespect of—
			particular employments, or
			employments generally.
		Any adjustment required by section 866 of an accounting debit that ispartly referable to an amount to which that section applies and partly toother matters must be made on a just and reasonable basis.
		In making a calculation for tax purposes that has to be made before the endof the 9 month period mentioned in section 866(2), it must be assumed that anyremuneration which is unpaid when the calculation is made will not be paidbefore the end of that period.
		But if the remuneration is subsequently paid before the end of the period,nothing in subsection (4) prevents the calculation being revised and any taxreturn being amended accordingly.
		For the purposes of section 866 and this section, remuneration is paid whenit—
			is treated as received by an employee for the purposes of ITEPA 2003 bysection 18 or 19 of that Act (receipt of money and non-money earnings), or
			would be so treated if it were not exempt income.
		In section 866 and this section—
			  * “employee” includes an office-holder and so “employment” includes an office, and 
			  * “remuneration” means an amount which is or is treated as earnings for the purposes of ITEPA 2003. 
	Delayed payment of pension contributions
		This section applies if—
			a debit in respect of pension contributions is recognised by a company foraccounting purposes, and
			the contributions are not paid until after the end of the period of accountin which the debit is recognised.
		The contributions may be brought into account for the purposes of this Partonly when they are paid.
		For the purposes of this section “pension contributions” means—
			sums paid by an employer by way of contributions under a registered pensionscheme,
			sums paid to the trustees or managers of such a scheme that are treated asif they were the payment of contributions under the pension scheme (seesection 199 of FA 2004), or
			expenses within section 246(3) of FA 2004 (expenditure on benefits underemployer-financed retirement benefits schemes).
		Any adjustment required by this section of an accounting debit that ispartly referable to an amount to which this section applies and partly toother matters must be made on a just and reasonable basis.
	Bad debts etc
		No debit may be brought into account for the purposes of this Part inrespect of a debt owed to the company, except—
			by way of impairment loss, or
			so far as the debt is released as part of a statutory insolvencyarrangement.
		If a debt is so released, any gain in respect of the release that isbrought into account for accounting purposes by the debtor is disregarded forthe purposes of this Part.
		Any other gain in respect of an unpaid debt in respect of an intangiblefixed asset that is brought into account by the debtor for accounting purposesis treated for the purposes of section 721 (receipts recognised as theyaccrue) as a gain in respect of an intangible fixed asset.
		Any adjustment required by this section of an accounting gain or loss thatis partly referable to an amount affected by this section and partly to othermatters must be made on a just and reasonable basis.
		In this section “debt” includes an obligation or liability that falls to bedischarged otherwise than by the payment of money.

Controlled foreign companies
	Assumptions for calculating chargeable profits
		In calculating the amount mentioned in section 747(6) of ICTA (chargeableprofits of controlled foreign company), the following assumptions must be madewhen applying this Part.
		It is assumed that any intangible fixed asset acquired or created by thecompany before the beginning of the first relevant accounting period wasacquired or created by the company at the beginning of that accounting periodat a cost equal to its value recognised for accounting purposes at that time.
		The “first relevant accounting period” is the first accounting period—
			in respect of which an apportionment under section 747(3) of ICTA falls tobe made, or
			which is an ADP exempt period.
		It is assumed that the company—
			has not claimed any relief under Chapter 7 (roll-over relief in case ofreinvestment), or
			made any provisional declaration of entitlement to such relief,
				and accordingly paragraph 4(1) of Schedule 24 to ICTA (assumption that allavailable reliefs have been claimed) is ignored to that extent.
		But if notice is given in accordance with paragraph 4(2) of Schedule 24 toICTA requesting that subsection (4) should not apply, it does not apply tosuch claims as are specified in the notice to the extent so specified.
		Expressions used in this section that are defined for the purposes ofChapter 4 of Part 17 of ICTA (controlled foreign companies) have the samemeaning in this section.
		See, in particular, paragraph 1(6) of Schedule 24 to that Act for themeaning of “ADP exempt period”).
		The assumption in subsection (2) does not affect the determination of thequestion whether this Part applies to an asset in accordance with section 882(application of this Part to assets created or acquired on or after 1 April2002).

Chapter 15Adjustments on change of accounting policy
	Introductory
		Introduction to Chapter
			This Chapter applies if—
				there is a change of accounting policy in drawing up a company’s accountsfrom one period of account to the next, and
				the approach in each of those periods accords with the law and practiceapplicable in relation to that period.
			In this Chapter—
				the first of those periods of account is referred to as “the earlierperiod”, and
				the next is referred to as “the later period”.
			This Chapter applies, in particular, if—
				the company prepares accounts for the earlier period in accordance with UKgenerally accepted accounting practice and for the later period in accordancewith international accounting standards, or
				the company prepares accounts for the earlier period in accordance withinternational accounting standards and for the later period in accordance withUK generally accepted accounting practice.
	Change of policy involving change of value
		Adjustments in respect of change
			This section and section 873 apply if—
				as a result of the change of accounting policy there is a difference (“theaccounting difference”) between—
				the accounting value of an intangible fixed asset of the company at the endof the earlier period, and
				the accounting value of that asset at the beginning of the later period,and
				no election has been made in respect of the asset under section 730(writing down at fixed rate: election for fixed-rate basis).
			If there is an increase in that value, a corresponding credit must bebrought into account for tax purposes in the later period.
			If there is a decrease in that value, a corresponding debit must be broughtinto account for tax purposes in the later period.
			The amount of the credit or debit is—
				[![](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_040)](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_040?view=plain)
			where—
				  * D is the accounting difference, 
				  * WDVE is the tax written-down value of the asset at the end of the earlier period, and 
				  * AVE is the accounting value of the asset at the end of the earlier period. 
			But if subsection (2) applies, the credit must not exceed—
				the sum of debits brought into account for tax purposes in respect of theasset before the later period, less
				the sum of the credits so brought into account.
			This section is subject to section 878 (exclusion of credits or debitsbrought into account under other provisions).
		Effect of application of section 872 in later period and subsequently
			A credit or debit that is required to be brought into account under section872 is treated as arising at the beginning of the later period (“the relevanttime”).
			If a credit is to be brought into account, the tax written-down value ofthe asset at the relevant time is the sum of—
				the tax written-down value of the asset at the end of the earlier period,and
				the credit.
			If a debit is to be brought into account, the tax written-down value of theasset at the relevant time is—
				the tax written-down value of the asset at the end of the earlier period,less
				the debit.
			After the relevant time the cost recognised for tax purposes is the sum of—
				the tax written-down value given by subsection (2) or (3), and
				the cost recognised for tax purposes of any subsequent expenditure on theasset that is capitalised for accounting purposes.
			After the relevant time the tax written-down value is determined takingaccount only of subsequent credits and debits.
	Change of policy involving disaggregation
		Original asset not subject to fixed-rate writing down
			This section and section 875 apply if—
				the change of accounting policy results in an intangible fixed asset of thecompany that was treated as one asset (“the original asset”) in the earlierperiod being treated as two or more assets (“the resulting assets”) in thelater period,
				there is a difference (“the accounting difference”) between—
				the accounting value of the original asset at the end of the earlierperiod, and
				the sum of the accounting values of the resulting assets at the beginningof the later period,
				no election under section 730 (writing down at fixed rate: election forfixed-rate basis) has been or is subsequently made in respect of the originalasset, and
				no such election is subsequently made in respect of any of the resultingassets.
			If the accounting difference is an increase, a corresponding credit must bebrought into account for tax purposes in the later period.
			If the accounting difference is a decrease, a corresponding debit must bebrought into account for tax purposes in the later period.
			The credit or debit is—
				[![](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_041)](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_041?view=plain)
			where—
				  * D is the accounting difference, 
				  * WDVE is the tax written-down value of the original asset at the end of the earlier period, and 
				  * AVE is the accounting value of that asset at the end of that period. 
			But if subsection (2) applies the credit must not exceed—
				the sum of the debits brought into account for tax purposes in respect ofthe original asset before the later period, less
				the sum of the credits so brought into account.
			This section is subject to section 878 (exclusion of credits or debitsbrought into account under other provisions).
		Effect of application of section 874 in later period and subsequently
			A credit or debit that is required to be brought into account under section874 is treated as arising at the beginning of the later period (“the relevanttime”).
			If section 874(2) applies, the tax written-down value of each resultingasset at the relevant time is—
				[![](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_042)](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_042?view=plain)
			where—
				  * WDVE is the tax written-down value of the original asset at the end of the earlier period,

				  * AV is the accounting value of the resulting asset in question at the relevant time, and 
				  * TAV is the sum of the accounting values of all the resulting assets at the relevant time. 
			If section 874(3) applies, the tax written-down value of each resultingasset at the relevant time is—
			[![](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_043)](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_043?view=plain)
			where—
				  * WDVE, AV and TAV have the same meaning as in subsection (2), and

				the tax written-down value given by subsection (2) or, as the case may be,subsection (3), and
				the cost recognised for tax purposes of any subsequent expenditure on theasset that is capitalised for accounting purposes.
			After the relevant time the tax written-down value for each resulting assetis determined taking account only of subsequent credits and debits.
		Original asset subject to fixed-rate writing down
			This section applies if—
				the change of accounting policy results in an intangible fixed asset of thecompany that was treated as one asset (“the original asset”) in the earlierperiod being treated as two or more assets (“the resulting assets”) in thelater period, and
				an election under section 730 (writing down at fixed rate: election forfixed-rate basis) has been or is subsequently made in respect of the originalasset.
			That election has effect—
				in relation to the original asset, for periods up to and including theearlier period, and
				in relation to each of the resulting assets, for the later period andsubsequent periods.
			The tax written-down value of each resulting asset at the beginning of thelater period (“the relevant time”) is—
				[![](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_044)](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_044?view=plain)
			where—

				  * AVL is the accounting value of the asset in question at the beginning of the later period, and 
				  * TAVL is the sum of the accounting values of all the resulting assets at the beginning of that period. 
			After the relevant time the cost recognised for tax purposes for eachresulting asset is the sum of—
				the tax written-down value given by subsection (3), and
				the cost recognised for tax purposes of any subsequent expenditure on theasset that is capitalised for accounting purposes.
			After the relevant time the tax written-down value for each resulting assetis determined taking account only of subsequent credits and debits.
		Election for fixed-rate writing down in relation to resulting asset
			This section applies if—
				the change of accounting policy results in an intangible fixed asset of thecompany that was treated as one asset (“the original undivided asset”) in theearlier period being treated as two or more assets (“the resulting assets”) inthe later period, and
				no election under section 730 (writing down at fixed rate: election forfixed-rate basis) has been or is subsequently made in respect of the originalundivided asset.
			An election under that section may be made in respect of any of theresulting assets.

			The appropriate proportion in relation to each resulting asset is—
				[![](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_045)](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_045?view=plain)
			where—
				  * AVL is the accounting value of that resulting asset at the beginning of the later period, and 
				  * TAVL is the sum of the accounting values of all the resulting assets at the beginning of that period. 
	Supplementary
		Exclusion of credits or debits brought into account under otherprovisions
			A credit or debit is not required to be brought into account under thisChapter so far as a credit or debit representing the accounting difference inquestion is brought into account for tax purposes under a provision specifiedin subsection (2).
			Those provisions are—
				section 723 (revaluation),
				section 725 (reversal of previous accounting loss), or
				section 732 (reversal of previous accounting gain).
		Subsequent events affecting asset subject to adjustment under thisChapter
			On a further change of accounting policy affecting an intangible fixedasset in relation to which this Chapter has applied, the previous provisionsof this Chapter apply again.

Introduction
	Overview of Chapter
		This Chapter—
			sets out a general rule limiting the application of this Part to certainassets (see section 882(1): application of this Part to assets created oracquired on or after 1 April 2002),
			makes provision about when assets are treated as created or acquired (seesections 883 to 889),
			makes special provision about particular kinds of assets (see sections 890to 897), and
			provides how roll-over relief is to apply in some circumstances whereassets excluded by the general rule mentioned in paragraph (a) are involved(see sections 898 and 899).
	Meaning of “pre-FA 2002 assets”
		Intangible fixed assets which are excluded from the application of this Partby the general rule mentioned in section 880(a) (subject to any expressprovision to the contrary) are referred to in this Part as “pre-FA 2002assets”.

General rule
	Application of this Part to assets created or acquired on or after 1April 2002
		The general rule is that this Part applies only to intangible fixed assetsof a company (“the company”) that—
			are created by the company on or after 1 April 2002,
			are acquired by the company on or after that date from a person who at thetime of the acquisition is not a related party in relation to the company, or
			are acquired by the company on or after that date in case A, B or C from aperson who at the time of the acquisition is a related party in relation tothe company.
		For provisions explaining when assets are treated as created or acquired,see sections 883 to 889.
		Case A is where the asset is acquired from a company in relation to whichthe asset was a chargeable intangible asset immediately before theacquisition.
		Case B is where the asset is acquired from a person (“the intermediary”)who acquired the asset on or after 1 April 2002 from a third person—
			who was not at the time of the intermediary’s acquisition a related partyin relation—
			to the intermediary, or
			if the intermediary was not a company, to a company in relation to whichthe intermediary was a related party, and
			who is not, at the time of the acquisition by the company, a related partyin relation to the company.
		Case C is where the asset was created on or after 1 April 2002 by theperson from whom it is acquired or any other person.
		The general rule in subsection (1) is subject to—
			section 890 (fungible assets: application of section 858),
			section 892 (certain assets acquired on transfer of a business),
			section 893 (assets whose value derives from pre-FA 2002 assets),
			section 895 (assets acquired in connection with disposals of pre-FA 2002assets),
			section 897 (application to pre-FA 2002 assets consisting oftelecommunication rights),
			sections 898 and 899 (application of roll-over relief in relation to somepre-FA 2002 assets), and
			section 905 (pre-FA 2002 assets: Lloyd’s syndicate capacity).
		This section does not restrict the application of this Part in accordancewith section 896 (application to royalties) (but see section 896(3)).

When assets are treated as created or acquired
	Assets treated as created or acquired when expenditure incurred
		This section—
			applies for the purposes of section 882 (application of this Part to assetscreated or acquired on or after 1 April 2002), and
			applies to all intangible assets except those to which the provisionsspecified in subsection (2) apply.
		The provisions referred to in subsection (1)(b) are—
			section 884 (internally-generated goodwill: time of creation),
			section 885 (certain other internally-generated assets: time of creation),and
			section 886 (assets representing production expenditure on films: time ofcreation).
		An intangible asset to which this section applies is treated as created oracquired on or after 1 April 2002 so far as expenditure on its creation oracquisition is incurred on or after that date.
		As to whether expenditure on the creation or acquisition of the asset isincurred on or after 1 April 2002, see sections 887 to 889.
		If only part of the expenditure on the creation or acquisition of the assetis incurred on or after 1 April 2002—
			this Part applies as if there were a separate asset representing theexpenditure so incurred, and
			the alternative enactments apply as if there were a separate assetrepresenting the expenditure not so incurred.
		In subsection (5) “the alternative enactments” means the enactments thatapply where this Part does not apply.
		Any apportionment necessary for the purposes of subsection (5) must be madeon a just and reasonable basis.
	Internally-generated goodwill: time of creation
		For the purposes of section 882 (application of this Part to assets created oracquired on or after 1 April 2002) internally-generated goodwill is treated ascreated before (and not on or after) 1 April 2002 if the business in questionwas carried on at any time before 1 April 2002 by the company or a relatedparty.
	Certain other internally-generated assets: time of creation
		This section—
			applies for the purposes of section 882 (application of this Part to assetscreated or acquired on or after 1 April 2002), and
			applies to an internally-generated asset representing non-qualifyingexpenditure.
		In this section “non-qualifying expenditure” means expenditure that underthe law as it was before 1 April 2002 is not qualifying expenditure for thepurposes of any allowance under CAA 2001.
		If only part of the expenditure on the creation or acquisition of the assetis non-qualifying expenditure, this Part applies as if there were separateassets representing the non-qualifying expenditure and the other expenditure.
		If this Part does not apply to the asset representing the non-qualifyingexpenditure, the alternative enactments also apply as if there were a separateasset representing that expenditure.
		In subsection (4) “the alternative enactments” means the enactments thatapply where this Part does not apply.
		Any apportionment necessary for the purposes of subsection (3) or (4) mustbe made on a just and reasonable basis.
		An asset to which this section applies is treated for the purposes ofsection 882 as created before (and not on or after) 1 April 2002 if the assetin question was held at any time before that date by the company or a relatedparty.
	Assets representing production expenditure on films: time of creation
		In determining for the purposes of this Part whether an asset representingproduction expenditure on a film was created before 1 April 2002 or on orafter that date, the asset is treated as created when the film is completed.
		In this section—
			“completed” has the same meaning as in Part 15 (see section 1181(5)),
			“film” has the same meaning as in that Part (see section 1181), and
			“production expenditure” has the same meaning as in that Part (see section1184).

When expenditure treated as incurred
	General rule
		For the purposes of section 883 (assets treated as created or acquired whenexpenditure incurred) the general rule is that expenditure on the acquisitionof an asset is treated as incurred when it is recognised for accountingpurposes.
		This is subject to—
			  * section 888 (cases where chargeable gains rule applies), and 
			  * section 889 (cases where capital allowances general rule applies). 
	Cases where chargeable gains rule applies
		This section applies if—
			expenditure on the acquisition of an asset does not qualify for any form oftax relief against income under the law as it was before 1 April 2002,
			that expenditure would be treated as incurred on or after that date underthe general rule in section 887, and
			the relevant disposal of the asset is treated as occurring before that datefor the purposes of TCGA 1992 or would be so treated under the law as it wasbefore 1 April 2002.
		For the purposes of section 883 (assets treated as created or acquired whenexpenditure incurred), the expenditure is treated as incurred before 1 April2002.
		In subsection (1) “the relevant disposal” means the disposal on which theacquisition mentioned in subsection (1)(a) occurred.
	Cases where capital allowances general rule applies
		This section applies if under the law as it was before 1 April 2002expenditure on the creation or acquisition of an asset is qualifyingexpenditure for the purposes of any allowance under CAA 2001.
		For the purposes of section 883 (assets treated as created or acquired whenexpenditure incurred) the expenditure is treated as incurred when anunconditional obligation to pay it arises.
		For this purpose the fact that the whole or part of the expenditure is notrequired to be paid until a later date does not prevent there being anunconditional obligation to pay it.

Fungible assets
	Fungible assets: application of section 858
		This section and section 891 apply for the purposes of this Chapter inrelation to assets to which section 858 (treatment of fungible assets)applies.
		Section 858 applies as if—
			pre-FA 2002 assets, and
			intangible fixed assets that are not pre-FA 2002 assets,
				were assets of different kinds.
		If section 858 applies (whether or not it is a case where subsection (2)has effect)—
			a single asset comprising pre-FA 2002 assets is treated as itself being apre-FA 2002 asset, and
			a single asset comprising intangible fixed assets that are not pre-FA 2002assets is treated as itself being an asset to which this Part applies.
	Realisation and acquisition of fungible assets
		Subsection (2) applies if—
			a company realises a fungible asset, and
			apart from section 890(2), the asset would be treated as part of a singleasset comprising both pre-FA 2002 assets and assets that are not pre-FA 2002assets.
		The realisation is treated as diminishing the single asset of the companycomprising pre-FA 2002 assets in priority to diminishing the single asset ofthe company comprising assets that are not pre-FA 2002 assets.
		Fungible assets acquired by a company that would not otherwise be treatedas pre-FA 2002 assets are so treated so far as they are identified, inaccordance with the following rules, with pre-FA 2002 assets realised by thecompany.
		Rule 1 is that assets acquired are identified with pre-FA 2002 assets ofthe same kind realised by the company within the period beginning 30 daysbefore and ending 30 days after the date of the acquisition.
		The reference in subsection (4) to assets “of the same kind” is to assetsthat are, or but for section 890(2) would be, treated as part of a singleasset because of section 858.
		Rule 2 is that assets realised earlier are identified before assetsrealised later.
		Rule 3 is that assets acquired earlier are identified before assetsacquired later.
		In this section “fungible asset” means an intangible fixed asset to whichsection 858 applies.

Assets treated as pre-FA 2002 assets
	Certain assets acquired on transfer of business
		This section applies if—
			a company (“the transferor”) transfers to another company (“thetransferee”) an asset that is a pre-FA 2002 asset in the hands of thetransferor company,
			the transfer is one in relation to which the transferor is treated for thepurposes of TCGA 1992 as disposing of the asset for a consideration thatsecures that neither a gain nor a loss accrues to it, and
			it is so treated because of a provision specified in subsection (2).
		The provisions are—
			section 139 of TCGA 1992 (reconstruction involving transfer of business),
			section 140A of that Act (transfer or division of UK business), and
			section 140E of that Act (merger leaving assets within UK tax charge).
		In the hands of the transferee the asset is treated for the purposes ofthis Part as a pre-FA 2002 asset.
		This section does not apply if the transfer mentioned in subsection (1)occurred before 28 June 2002.
	Assets whose value derives from pre-FA 2002 assets
		This section applies if—
			on or after 1 April 2002 a company (“the acquiring company”) acquires anintangible fixed asset (“the acquired asset”) from a person (“thetransferor”),
			the acquired asset is created on or after 1 April 2002,
			at the time of the acquisition the transferor and the acquiring company arerelated parties,
			the value of the acquired asset derives in whole or in part from any otherasset (“the other asset”), and
			the other asset meets the preserved status conditions (see section 894).
		In the hands of the acquiring company the acquired asset is treated for thepurposes of this Part as a pre-FA 2002 asset so far as its value derives fromthe other asset.
		If only part of the value of the acquired asset derives from the otherasset—
			this Part applies as if there were a separate asset representing the partof the value that does not so derive, and
			the alternative enactments apply as if there were a separate assetrepresenting the part of the value that does so derive.
		In subsection (3) “the alternative enactments” means the enactments thatapply where this Part does not apply.
		For the purposes of this section the cases in which the value of an assetmay be derived from any other asset include any case where—
			assets have been merged or divided,
			assets have changed their nature, or
			rights or interests in or over assets have been created or extinguished.
		Section 894 supplements this section.
	The preserved status conditions etc
		For the purposes of section 893(1) the other asset meets the preservedstatus conditions if subsections (2) and (3) apply.
		This subsection applies if on or after 1 April 2002 the other asset—
			has been a pre-FA 2002 asset in the hands of the transferor at a time whenthe transferor and the acquiring company were related parties, or
			has been a pre-FA 2002 asset in the hands of any other person at a timewhen—
			the other person and the acquiring company were related parties, or
			the other person and the transferor were related parties.
		This subsection applies if the other asset has not at any time on or after5 December 2005 been a chargeable intangible asset in the hands of—
			the acquiring company,
			a person who is a related party in relation to that company, or
			the transferor.
		It does not matter for the purposes of section 893(1)(b) who created theacquired asset.
		Any apportionment necessary for the purposes of section 893(3) must be madeon a just and reasonable basis.
		Sections 883 to 889 (provisions explaining when assets are treated ascreated or acquired) apply for the purposes of section 893 as they apply forthe purposes of section 882.
		Expressions used in this section have the same meaning as in section 893.
	Assets acquired in connection with disposals of pre-FA 2002 assets
		This section applies if—
			a person disposes of an asset which is a pre-FA 2002 asset in the person’shands at the time of the disposal,
			a company acquires an intangible fixed asset directly or indirectly inconsequence of the disposal or otherwise in connection with it,
			the company and the person are related parties at the time of the disposal,and
			the acquired asset would be a chargeable intangible asset in the hands ofthe company at the time of the acquisition apart from this section.
		The acquired asset is treated for the purposes of this Part as a pre-FA2002 asset in the company’s hands.
		For the purposes of this section—
			“asset”, in relation to any disposal, means any asset for the purposes ofTCGA 1992,
			a person “disposes of” an asset if, for the purposes of that Act, theperson makes a part disposal of the asset or any other disposal of it, and
			the time at which a disposal of an asset is made is the time at which it ismade for the purposes of that Act.
		For the purposes of this section it does not matter whether—
			the asset that the person disposes of is the same asset as the acquiredasset,
			the acquired asset is acquired at the time of the disposal, or
			the acquired asset is acquired by merging assets or otherwise.

Application of Part to royalties and telecommunication rights
	Application to royalties
		This Part—
			applies to royalties recognised for accounting purposes on or after 1 April2002, and
			does not apply to royalties recognised for accounting purposes before thatdate.
		But subsection (1) is subject to subsection (3).
		This section does not authorise or require an amount to be brought intoaccount in connection with the realisation of a pre-FA 2002 asset.
		In this section “realisation” has the same meaning as in Chapter 4 (seesection 734).
	Application to pre-FA 2002 assets consisting of telecommunicationrights
		This Part applies to a pre-FA 2002 asset consisting of a licence or otherright within Chapter 10 of Part 2 of ITTOIA (certain telecommunication rights)(see section 146 of that Act).
		This Part applies in relation to such assets as if amounts brought intoaccount for tax purposes under Schedule 23 to FA 2000 in accounting periodsending before 1 April 2002 had been so brought into account under this Part.
		This subsection applies if the asset—
			was acquired before the beginning of the first accounting period ending onor after 1 April 2002, and
			was a chargeable intangible asset immediately after the beginning of thatperiod.
		If subsection (3) applies, the asset is treated for the purposes of Chapter7 (roll-over relief on realisation and reinvestment) as if it had been achargeable intangible asset at all material times between its acquisition andthe beginning of the first accounting period ending on or after 1 April 2002.

Roll-over relief for disposals of pre-FA 2002 assets
	Relief where assets disposed of on or after 1 April 2002
		This section applies if a company disposes of a pre-FA 2002 asset on orafter 1 April 2002.
		Chapter 7 (roll-over relief in case of realisation and reinvestment)applies as if—
			references to the realisation of the old asset were references to itsdisposal,
			references to its being a chargeable intangible asset were references toits being a chargeable asset within TCGA 1992 (see section 900),
			references to the proceeds of its realisation were references to the netproceeds of disposal under that Act (see subsection (3)), and
			references to its cost recognised for tax purposes were references to thecost under that Act (see subsection (4)).
		For the purposes of subsection (2)(c) the net proceeds of disposal underTCGA 1992 are taken to be the amount or value of the consideration for thedisposal, less any incidental costs of making the disposal that would beallowable as a deduction under section 38(1)(c) of that Act.
		For the purposes of subsection (2)(d) the cost under TCGA 1992 is taken tobe an amount equal to the difference between—
			the net proceeds of disposal (as defined in subsection (3)), and
			the amount of the chargeable gain on the disposal.
		Section 850 (part realisation involving related party acquisition:exclusion of roll-over relief) does not apply in a case where Chapter 7applies because of this section.
		References in this section to the disposal of an asset have the samemeaning as in TCGA 1992.
	Relief where degrouping charge on asset arises on or after 1 April2002
		This section applies if—
			a company is treated under section 179(3) or (6) of TCGA 1992 (degroupingcharge) as having sold and reacquired a pre-FA 2002 asset, and
			under section 179(4) or (8) of that Act the gain is treated as accruing onor after 1 April 2002.
		Chapter 7 (roll-over relief in case of realisation and reinvestment)applies as specified in section 898(2) and with the additional modificationsspecified in subsections (3) to (5).
		In section 755 (conditions relating to the old asset and its realisation),for the references to the old asset being a chargeable intangible assetthroughout the period during which it was held by the company substitutereferences to its being a chargeable asset within TCGA 1992 throughout theperiod during which it was held by the company referred to in section 179 ofthat Act as “company B”.
		In section 756(1) (conditions relating to expenditure on other assets), forthe references to the date of realisation of the old asset substitutereferences—
			in a case within section 179(3) of TCGA 1992, to the time at which the gainis treated as accruing under section 179(4) of that Act, and
			in a case within subsection 179(6) of that Act, to the time at which thegain is treated as accruing under section 179(8) of that Act.
		For references to the proceeds of realisation substitute references to theamount of the consideration for which the company is treated under TCGA 1992as having sold and reacquired the asset.
		For the meaning of “chargeable asset within TCGA 1992”, see section 900.
		Section 850 (part realisation involving related party: exclusion of roll-over relief) does not apply in a case where Chapter 7 applies because of thissection.
	Meaning of “chargeable asset within TCGA” in sections 898 and 899
		For the purposes of sections 898 and 899 an asset is a chargeable assetwithin TCGA 1992 in relation to a company at any time if—
			any gain accruing to the company on the disposal of it at that time wouldbe a chargeable gain within the meaning of that Act,
			condition A or condition B is met in relation to the company, and
			double tax relief is not available to the company at that time.
		Condition A is that at that time the company is UK resident or ordinarilyUK resident.
		Condition B is that the gain would form part of the company’s chargeableprofits for corporation tax purposes as a result of section 10B of TCGA 1992(non-resident company with United Kingdom permanent establishment).
		For the purposes of subsection (1) double tax relief is available to thecompany if it would be treated for the purposes of any double taxation reliefarrangements as not liable in the United Kingdom to tax on any gain accruingto it on a disposal of the asset.
		References in this section to the disposal of an asset have the samemeaning as in TCGA 1992.

Chapter 17Insurance companies
	Effect of application of the I minus E basis: non-trading amounts
		Effect of application of the I minus E basis: non-trading amounts
			The effect of applying the I minus E basis for an accounting period inrelation to life assurance business carried on by an insurance company is asfollows.
			Credits or debits falling to be brought into account under this Part inrespect of intangible fixed assets of the company referable to that businessare not brought into account as mentioned in section 747 (assets held forpurposes of trade).
			Instead, those credits or debits are brought into account under section 751(non-trading gains and losses) as non-trading credits or, as the case may be,non-trading debits.
	Excluded assets and computer software
		Excluded assets
			Except as respects royalties, this Part does not apply to an intangiblefixed asset so far as it is held by an insurance company for the purposes ofits life assurance business.
			Accordingly, section 810(1) (which makes provision in the same terms assubsection (1) in relation to assets held for the purposes of any mutual tradeor business) does not apply in relation to assets held for the purposes oflife assurance business.
			Subsection (1) does not apply to computer software.
			Sections 801 and 802 apply so far as assets are excluded by this section asthey apply so far as assets are excluded because of sections 810 to 813.
		Elections to exclude capital expenditure on computer software
			An insurance company that carries on life assurance business may make anelection under section 815 (election to exclude capital expenditure onsoftware) in respect of so much of any capital expenditure on computersoftware as is not referable to its basic life assurance and general annuitybusiness.
			In subsection (1) “capital expenditure” has the same meaning as if thissection were in CAA 2001.
	Miscellaneous
		Transfers of life assurance business: transfers of assets treated astax-neutral
			A transfer of intangible fixed assets to which this section applies is tax-neutral for the purposes of this Part (see section 776).
			This section applies to a transfer of intangible fixed assets if—
				the assets are included in a transfer within subsection (3),
				immediately before the transfer the intangible fixed assets are chargeableintangible assets in relation to the company making the transfer, and
				immediately after the transfer the intangible fixed assets are chargeableintangible assets in relation to the company to which the transfer is made.
			A transfer is within this subsection if it is—
				a transfer of business consisting of the effecting or carrying out of long-term business which has effect under an insurance business transfer scheme, or
				a qualifying overseas transfer.
		Pre-FA 2002 assets: Lloyd’s syndicate capacity
			The general rule in section 882 (this Part not to apply to pre-FA 2002assets) does not apply if the intangible fixed asset consists of the rights ofa member of Lloyd’s under a syndicate within the meaning of Chapter 5 of Part4 of FA 1994 (taxation of corporate members of Lloyd's).
			This Part applies in relation to the asset as respects amounts to bebrought into account for tax purposes in accounting periods ending on or after1 April 2002.
			For the purposes of section 729(5) (writing down on accounting basis:calculation of amount of debit for tax purposes) as it applies to the firstaccounting period ending on or after 1 April 2002, the tax written down valueof the asset must be calculated under section 742 in accordance withsubsection (4).
			That value must be calculated as if the debits to be deducted under section742 included all accounting losses previously recognised in respect of theasset.
			It does not matter for the purposes of subsection (4) if those accountinglosses previously gave rise to a deduction for tax purposes.
			This subsection applies if an asset within subsection (1)—
				was acquired before the beginning of the first accounting period ending onor after 1 April 2002, and
				is a chargeable intangible asset immediately after the beginning of thatperiod.
			If subsection (6) applies, the asset is treated for the purposes of Chapter7 (roll-over relief on realisation and reinvestment) as if it had been achargeable intangible asset at all material times between its acquisition andthe beginning of the first accounting period ending on or after 1 April 2002.
			For the purposes of this section, an asset is treated as acquired at thesame time as it would be treated as acquired for the purposes of section 882(see sections 883 to 885).

Chapter 18Priority rules
	Priority of this Part for corporation tax purposes
		The amounts to be brought into account in accordance with this Part inrespect of any matter are the only amounts to be brought into account forcorporation tax purposes in respect of that matter.
		Subsection (1) is subject to any indication to the contrary.
		In particular, see—
			section 1308 (expenditure brought into account in determining value ofintangible asset), and
			section 83(2ZA) of FA 1989 (life assurance: receipts to be taken intoaccount).

Chapter 1Introduction
	Overview of Part
		This Part applies the charge to corporation tax on income to—
			profits from disposals of know-how (see Chapter 2), and
			profits from sales of patent rights (see Chapter 3).
		This Part also provides for relief from corporation tax on patent income(see Chapter 4).
		Chapter 5 contains supplementary provision relevant to Chapters 2 to 4.
		This Part needs to be read in the light of Part 8 (intangible fixedassets).
		See in particular the following provisions of Part 8, which are relevant tothe application of that Part—
			section 713 (meaning of “intangible fixed asset”),
			Chapter 16 (which limits the application of Part 8 to assets which are notpre-FA 2002 assets within the meaning of section 881), and
			section 906 (which contains a rule about the priority of Part 8 forcorporation tax purposes).

Chapter 2Disposals of know-how
	Charge to tax on profits from disposals of know-how
		The charge to corporation tax on income applies to profits arising whereconsideration is received by a company—
			for the disposal of know-how, or
			for giving, or wholly or partly fulfilling, an undertaking which—
			is given in connection with a disposal of know-how, and
			restricts or is designed to restrict any person’s activities in any way.
		For the purposes of subsection (1)(b), it does not matter whether or notthe undertaking is legally enforceable.
		Subsection (1) is subject to the exceptions in section 909.
		In this Chapter “know-how” means any industrial information or techniqueslikely to assist in—
			manufacturing or processing goods or materials,
			working a source of mineral deposits (including searching for, discoveringor testing mineral deposits or obtaining access to them), or
			carrying out any agricultural, forestry or fishing operations.
		In subsection (4)—
			“mineral deposits” includes any natural deposits capable of being lifted orextracted from the earth and for this purpose geothermal energy is treated asa natural deposit, and
			“source of mineral deposits” includes a mine, an oil well and a source ofgeothermal energy.
	Exceptions to charge under section 908
		Section 908 does not apply in the following cases.
		Case A is if the consideration is brought into account under section 462 ofCAA 2001 (disposal values).
		Case B is if the consideration is dealt with in relation to the companyreceiving it as a trading receipt under section 177(2) (disposal of know-howif trade continues to be carried on).
		Case C is if the consideration is dealt with in relation to the personreceiving it as a capital receipt for goodwill under section 178(2) (disposalof know-how as part of disposal of all or part of a trade).
		Case D is if the disposal of the know-how is by way of a sale and—
			the buyer is a body of persons over which the seller has control,
			the seller is a body of persons over which the buyer has control, or
			the buyer and the seller are both bodies of persons and another person hascontrol over both of them.
		In subsection (5) “body of persons” includes a firm.
	Profits charged under section 908
		The profits charged under section 908 are—
			the amount of the consideration, less
			any expenditure incurred by the company wholly and exclusively in theacquisition or disposal of the know-how.
		Such expenditure may not be taken into account more than once, whetherunder this section or otherwise.
		This section needs to be read with section 926 (contributions toexpenditure).

Chapter 3Sales of patent rights
	Introductory
		Overview of Chapter
			This Chapter—
				applies the charge to corporation tax on income to profits from sales ofpatent rights (see sections 912 and 913),
				contains provision about how the amount chargeable is taxed (see sections914 to 918), and
				contains related provision, including provision relevant to the applicationof the Chapter (see sections 919 to 923).
			Section 848 of ITA 2007, under which a sum representing income tax deductedunder section 910 of that Act (deduction from payment to non-UK residents inrespect of sale of patent rights) is treated as income tax paid by therecipient, is also relevant to the tax treatment of payments made to non-UKresident companies in respect of sales of patent rights.
	Charge to tax
		Charge to tax on profits from sales of patent rights
			The charge to corporation tax on income applies to profits from sales by acompany of the whole or part of any patent rights.
			Subsection (1) applies in the case of a non-UK resident company if thepatent is granted under the laws of the United Kingdom.
			In this Chapter “patent rights” means the right to do or authorise thedoing of anything which, but for the right, would be an infringement of apatent.
		Profits charged under section 912
			A company’s profits from the sale of the whole or part of patent rightsare—
				any capital sum comprised in the proceeds of sale, less
				the deductible costs.
			The deductible costs are—
				the capital cost (if any) of the rights sold, and
				any incidental expenses incurred by the company in connection with thesale.
			If— 
				the company acquired the rights sold, or the rights out of which they weregranted, by purchase,
				the company has previously sold part of the purchased rights, and
				the proceeds of that sale, after deducting any incidental expenses,consisted wholly or partly of a capital sum,
					the capital cost is reduced by that sum.
			References in this Chapter to the capital cost of patent rights are to anycapital sum included in any price paid by the company to purchase—
				the rights, or
				the rights out of which they were granted.
			This section needs to be read with sections 924 (relief for expenses:patent income) and 926 (contributions to expenditure).
	Spreading of charge to tax
		UK resident companies: proceeds of sale not received in instalments
			This section applies if a company liable for tax under section 912—
				is UK resident, and
				does not receive the proceeds of sale in instalments.
			The appropriate fraction of the amount chargeable is taxed—
				in the accounting period in which the company receives the proceeds of sale(“the period of receipt”), and
				in successive accounting periods, until the expiry of the 6-year periodbeginning at the start of the period of receipt.
			The appropriate fraction is the same fraction of the amount chargeable asthe accounting period in question is of 6 years (or, in the last period, suchsmaller fraction of that amount as has not already been taxed).
			The company may elect that the whole of the amount chargeable is to betaxed instead in the period of receipt.
			An election under subsection (4) must be made within the two-year periodbeginning at the end of the period of receipt.
		UK resident companies: proceeds of sale received in instalments
			This section applies if a company liable for tax under section 912—
				is UK resident, and
				receives the proceeds of sale in instalments.
			The appropriate fraction of the amount chargeable in respect of eachinstalment is taxed—
				in the accounting period in which the company receives the instalment (“theperiod of receipt”), and
				in successive accounting periods, until the expiry of the 6-year periodbeginning at the start of the period of receipt.
			The appropriate fraction of the amount chargeable in respect of aninstalment is the same fraction of that amount as the accounting period inquestion is of 6 years (or, in the last period, such smaller fraction of theamount as has not already been taxed).
			The company may elect that the whole of any instalment is to be taxedinstead in the period of receipt.
			An election under subsection (4) must be made within the two-year periodbeginning at the end of the period of receipt.
		Non-UK resident companies: proceeds of sale not received ininstalments
			This section applies if a company liable for tax under section 912—
				is not UK resident, and
				does not receive the proceeds of sale in instalments.
			The whole of the amount chargeable is taxed in the accounting period inwhich the company receives the proceeds (“the period of receipt”).
			The company may elect instead that the amount chargeable—
				is to be treated as arising rateably in the accounting periods ending 6years from the start of the period of receipt, and
				is taxed accordingly.
			An election under subsection (3) must be made within the two-year periodbeginning at the end of the period of receipt.
			The election has effect in relation to accounting periods of the companyduring which the company is within the charge to corporation tax in respect ofany proceeds of the sale not consisting of a capital sum.
			Such repayments and assessments are to be made for each of the accountingperiods affected as are necessary to give effect to the election.
			Subsection (6) is subject to the qualifications in section 920 (adjustmentswhere tax has been deducted).
		Non-UK resident companies: proceeds of sale received in instalments
			This section applies if a company liable for tax under section 912—
				is not UK resident, and
				receives the proceeds of sale in instalments.
			The amount chargeable in respect of each instalment is taxed in theaccounting period in which the company receives the instalment (“the period ofreceipt”).
			The company may, for any instalment, elect instead that the amountchargeable in respect of the instalment—
				is to be treated as arising rateably in the accounting periods ending 6years from the start of the period of receipt, and
				is taxed accordingly.
			An election under subsection (3) must be made within the two-year periodbeginning at the end of the period of receipt.
			The election has effect in relation to accounting periods of the companyduring which the company is within the charge to corporation tax in respect ofany proceeds of the sale not consisting of a capital sum.
			Such repayments and assessments are to be made for each of the accountingperiods affected as are necessary to give effect to the election.
			Subsection (6) is subject to the qualifications in section 920 (adjustmentswhere tax has been deducted).
		Winding up of a body corporate
			If a body corporate which is liable for tax under section 912 commences tobe wound up, any amounts falling within subsection (2) are taxed in theaccounting period in which the winding up commences.
			The amounts are—
				any amounts which would have been chargeable in later accounting periodsunder section 914(2) or 915(2) (UK resident companies: spreading of charge totax), and
