		But this subsection does not apply if the company’s business is a propertybusiness (in which case subsection (2) applies instead).
		If the company is a company in relation to which section 76 of ICTA(expenses of insurance companies) applies, the expenses are treated asexpenses payable falling to be brought into account at Step 1 in subsection(7) of that section.
		If the trust is established more than 9 months after the end of the periodof account in which the expenses are incurred—
			for the purposes of subsection (2) the deduction is to be made for theperiod of account in which the trust is established, or
			for the purposes of subsection (3) or (4) the expenses are treated asreferable to the accounting period in which the trust is established.
		For the purposes of subsection (5) a trust is established when the deedunder which it is established is executed.
		So far as this section provides for a deduction to be allowed, it haseffect despite section 53 (no deduction for items of a capital nature incalculating trading profits), including that section as applied by section 210to the calculation of profits of a property business.

Chapter 1Introduction
	Introductory
		Overview of Part
			This Part provides for corporation tax relief in relation to employee shareacquisitions.
			Sections 1002 to 1005 relate to the interpretation of this Part.
			Chapter 2 provides for relief if shares are acquired by an employee oranother person because of the employee’s employment by a company.
			Chapter 3 provides for relief if—
				an employee or another person obtains an option to acquire shares becauseof the employee’s employment by a company, and
				shares are acquired pursuant to the option.
			Chapter 4 provides for additional relief in cases involving restrictedshares.
			Chapter 5 provides for additional relief in cases involving convertibleshares or convertible securities that are not shares.
			Chapter 6 deals with the relationship between the reliefs under this Partand other reliefs.
	Interpretation
		“Employment” 
			This section explains how references in this Part to employment (andrelated expressions) are to be read.
			“Employment” includes a former or prospective employment.
			References to employment by a company include references to holding anoffice with that company.
			Members of a company whose affairs are managed by its members are treatedas holding an office with the company.
		“Shares” etc
			In this Part “shares” includes—
				an interest in shares, and
				stock or an interest in stock.
			For the purposes of this Part shares are acquired by a person when theperson acquires a beneficial interest in them (and not, if different, whenthey are conveyed or transferred).
		Groups, consortiums and commercial associations of companies
			This section applies for the purposes of this Part.
			Two companies are members of the same group if one is a 51% subsidiary ofthe other or both are 51% subsidiaries of a third company.
			“Group transfer” means a transfer of a business, or a part of a business,from one company that is a member of a group to another company that is, ortwo or more companies that are, members of the group.
			A company is a parent company of another company if that other company isits 51% subsidiary.
			A company (“the consortium company”) is owned by a consortium if—
				five or fewer companies (“the shareholding companies”) between thembeneficially own at least 75% of the consortium company’s ordinary sharecapital, and
				each of the shareholding companies beneficially owns at least 10% of thatcapital.
			Each shareholding company is a member of the consortium.
			For the purposes of subsection (5) the shareholdings of members of a groupof companies are to be treated as held by a single company.
			And, in such a case, a member of the group of companies is a member of theconsortium if the member beneficially owns some of the consortium company’sordinary share capital.
			“Commercial association of companies” means a company together with such ofits associated companies (as defined in section 416 of ICTA) as carry onbusinesses that are of such a nature that the businesses of the company andthe associated companies, taken together, may be reasonably considered to makeup a single composite undertaking.
		Other definitions
			In this Part—
			  * “convertible securities” has the same meaning as in Chapter 3 of Part 7 of ITEPA 2003 (see section 436 of that Act), 
			  * “convertible shares” means shares that are— 
				convertible securities, or
				an interest in convertible securities,
					  * “the employee” has the meaning given by section 1007(1)(a) or 1015(1)(a) (as the case may be), 
					  * “the employing company” has the meaning given by section 1007(1) or 1015(1) (as the case may be), 
					  * “listed company” means a company— 
				whose shares are listed on a recognised stock exchange, and
				which is neither a close company nor a company that would be a close companyif it were UK resident,
					  * “market value” has the same meaning as in TCGA 1992 (see sections 272 and 273 of that Act), 
					  * “option” includes any right to acquire shares, 
					  * “ordinary shares” means shares forming part of a company’s ordinary share capital, 
					  * “the qualifying business” has the meaning given by section 1007(1)(b) or 1015(1)(b) (as the case may be), 
					  * “the recipient” has the meaning given by section 1007(1) or 1015(1) (as the case may be), 
					  * “the relevant employment” has the meaning given by section 1007(1)(b) or 1015(1)(b) (as the case may be), and 
					  * “restricted shares” means shares that are— 
				restricted securities, or
				a restricted interest in securities,
				for the purposes of Chapter 2 of Part 7 of ITEPA 2003 (see sections 423 and424 of that Act).

Chapter 2Relief if shares acquired by employee or other person
	Introductory
		Overview of Chapter
			This Chapter provides for relief if shares are acquired by an employee oranother person because of the employee’s employment by a company.
			Sections 1007 to 1009 set out the requirements that must be met for reliefto be available.
			Sections 1010 to 1012 set out how the amount of relief is calculated.
			Section 1013 sets out how the relief is given.
	Requirements to be met for relief to be available
		Basic requirements for relief under Chapter 2
			Relief under this Chapter is available to a company (“the employingcompany”) if—
				a person (“the employee”) has employment with the employing company,
				that employment (“the relevant employment”) is in relation to a businesswithin subsection (2) (“the qualifying business”),
				the employee or another person acquires shares because of the relevantemployment,
				the conditions set out in sections 1008 and 1009 are met as mentioned inthose sections, and
				relief under Chapter 3 is not available to the employing company inrelation to the acquisition of the shares.
					The person who acquires the shares is, in that capacity, called “therecipient”.
			A business is within this subsection so far as—
				the business is carried on by the employing company, and
				the employing company is within the charge to corporation tax in relationto the profits of the business.
		Conditions relating to shares acquired
			Each of the following conditions must be met in relation to the sharesacquired.
				  * _Condition 1_
				The shares are ordinary shares that are fully paid-up and not redeemable.
				  * _Condition 2_
			The shares are—
				shares of a class listed on a recognised stock exchange,
				shares in a company that is not under the control of another company, or
				shares in a company that is under the control of a listed company.
					  * _Condition 3_
				The shares are shares in—
				the employing company,
				a company that, when the shares are acquired, is a parent company of theemploying company,
				a company that, when the shares are acquired, is a member of a consortium thatowns the employing company,
				a company that, when the shares are acquired, is a member of a consortium thatowns a parent company of the employing company, or
				a company within subsection (2).
			A company (“company A”) is within this subsection if when the shares areacquired—
				the employing company or a parent company of the employing company is amember of a consortium that owns another company (“company B”), and
				company A is—
				a member of that consortium or a parent company of a member of thatconsortium, and
				a member of the same commercial association of companies as company B.
		Conditions relating to employee’s income tax position
			If the shares acquired are not restricted shares, the following conditionsmust be met in relation to the income tax position of the employee.
				  * _Condition 1_
				The employee is subject to a charge under ITEPA 2003 in relation to theacquisition of the shares.
				  * _Condition 2_
			Section 446UA of ITEPA 2003 does not apply in relation to the shares.
			If the shares acquired are restricted shares, the following condition mustbe met in relation to the income tax position of the employee.
				  * _The Condition_
			The employee—
				has, as a result of the acquisition of the shares, earnings within Chapter 1of Part 3 of ITEPA 2003 from the relevant employment that are subject to thecharge under Part 2 of that Act, or
				is not within paragraph (a) but will be subject to a charge under ITEPA 2003as a result of section 426 of that Act if an event occurs in relation to theshares that is a chargeable event for the purposes of that section.
			Subsection (4) applies if—
				the conditions are, or the condition is, not met, but
				the conditions or the condition would be met if at all material times theemployee had been a UK employee.
			This Chapter applies as if the employee had been a UK employee as mentionedin subsection (3)(b).
			The employee is a UK employee if—
				the employee is UK resident and ordinarily UK resident, and
				the duties of the relevant employment are performed in the United Kingdom.
	Calculation of amount of relief
		Calculation of relief if shares are neither restricted norconvertible
			If the shares acquired are neither restricted shares nor convertibleshares, the amount of relief to be given is an amount equal to—
				the market value of the shares when they are acquired, less
				the total amount or value of any consideration given by any person inrelation to the acquisition of the shares.
					This is subject to section 1012.
			The consideration mentioned in subsection (1)(b) does not include theperformance of any duties of, or in connection with, the relevant employment.
			A just and reasonable apportionment is to be made of any considerationgiven partly in relation to the acquisition of the shares and partly inrelation to other matters.
		Calculation of relief if shares are restricted or convertible
			If the shares acquired are restricted shares or convertible shares (orboth), the amount of relief to be given is calculated as follows.
				This is subject to section 1012.
			If the shares are restricted shares, the amount of relief is equal to theamount that, as a result of the acquisition of the shares, is earnings of theemployee within Chapter 1 of Part 3 of ITEPA 2003 from the relevantemployment.
			If the shares are convertible shares, the amount of relief is equal to theamount that, as a result of the acquisition of the shares, is earnings of theemployee within Chapter 1 of Part 3 of ITEPA 2003 from the relevantemployment.
			In calculating the employee’s earnings for this purpose the market value ofthe shares is to be determined as if they were not convertible shares.
			For the purposes of subsections (2) and (3) “earnings” does not include anyamount of exempt income (within the meaning of section 8 of ITEPA 2003).
			If the shares are both restricted and convertible, the total amount ofrelief is whichever is the greater of the amounts of relief given bysubsections (2) and (3) (or, if the amount is the same in each case, thatamount).
		Reduction in amount of relief
			This section applies if the relevant employment is in relation to both thequalifying business and a business (or part of a business) that is not withinsection 1007(2).
			The amount of relief is to be reduced by a just and reasonable amount.
	Giving of relief
		How the relief is given
			The relief is given for the accounting period in which the shares areacquired.
			The amount of relief is allowed as a deduction in calculating the profitsof the qualifying business for corporation tax purposes (subject tosubsections (3) and (4)).
			If the employing company is a company with investment business (as definedin section 1218), the amount of relief is treated as expenses of management ofthe company.
				But this subsection does not apply if the qualifying business is a propertybusiness (in which case subsection (2) applies instead).
			If the employing company is a company in relation to which section 76 ofICTA (expenses of insurance companies) applies, the amount of relief istreated as expenses payable falling to be brought into account at Step 1 insubsection (7) of that section.
			If the relevant employment is in relation to more than one business (orpart of a business) within section 1007(2), the relief is to be apportioned ona just and reasonable basis.

Chapter 3Relief if employee or other person obtains option to acquireshares
	Introductory
		Overview of Chapter
			This Chapter provides for relief if—
				an employee or another person obtains an option to acquire shares becauseof the employee’s employment by a company, and
				shares are acquired pursuant to the option.
			Sections 1015 to 1017 set out the requirements that must be met for reliefto be available.
			Sections 1018 to 1020 set out how the amount of relief is calculated.
			Section 1021 sets out how the relief is given.
			Sections 1022 and 1023 deal with cases in which a person obtains an optionto acquire shares in a company and that company is subsequently taken over.
			Section 1024 provides for relief to be given to a successor company if thequalifying business is transferred by group transfers.
	Requirements to be met for relief to be available
		Basic requirements for relief under Chapter 3
			Relief under this Chapter is available to a company (“the employingcompany”) if—
				a person (“the employee”) has employment with the employing company,
				that employment (“the relevant employment”) is in relation to a businesswithin subsection (2) (“the qualifying business”),
				the employee or another person obtains an option to acquire shares becauseof the relevant employment,
				the person who obtains the option acquires shares pursuant to the option,and
				the conditions set out in sections 1016 and 1017 are met as mentioned inthose sections.
					The person who obtains the option is, in that capacity, called “therecipient”.
			A business is within this subsection so far as—
				the business is carried on by the employing company, and
				the employing company is within the charge to corporation tax in relationto the profits of the business.
			If— 
				the recipient dies, and
				subsequently another person acquires shares pursuant to the option,
				this Chapter applies as if the recipient were alive and the shares wereacquired by the recipient.
		Conditions relating to shares acquired
			Each of the following conditions must be met in relation to the sharesacquired.
				  * _Condition 1_
				The shares are ordinary shares that are fully paid-up and not redeemable.
				  * _Condition 2_
			The shares are—
				shares of a class listed on a recognised stock exchange,
				shares in a company that is not under the control of another company, or
				shares in a company that is under the control of a listed company.
					  * _Condition 3_
				The shares are shares in—
				the employing company,
				a company that, when the option is obtained, is a parent company of theemploying company,
				a company that, when the option is obtained, is a member of a consortium thatowns the employing company,
				a company that, when the option is obtained, is a member of a consortium thatowns a parent company of the employing company,
				a company within subsection (2), or
				a qualifying successor company (see section 1022).
			A company (“company A”) is within this subsection if when the option isobtained—
				the employing company or a parent company of the employing company is amember of a consortium that owns another company (“company B”), and
				company A is—
				a member of that consortium or a parent company of a member of thatconsortium, and
				a member of the same commercial association of companies as company B.
		Condition relating to employee’s income tax position
			The following condition must be met in relation to the income tax positionof the employee.
				  * _The Condition_
				The acquisition of the shares is a chargeable event in relation to theemployee for the purposes of section 476 of ITEPA 2003 (whether or not anamount counts as employment income of the employee because of that event).
			Subsection (3) applies if the condition—
				is not met, but
				would be met if at all material times the employee had been a UK employee.
			This Chapter applies as if the employee had been a UK employee as mentionedin subsection (2)(b).
			The employee is a UK employee if—
				the employee is UK resident and ordinarily UK resident, and
				the duties of the relevant employment are performed in the United Kingdom.
			If the employee is dead when the shares are acquired, the condition is tobe treated as met if it would have been met had the employee been alive.
	Calculation of amount of relief
		Calculation of relief if shares are neither restricted norconvertible
			If the shares acquired are neither restricted shares nor convertibleshares, the amount of relief to be given is an amount equal to—
				the market value of the shares when they are acquired, less
				the total amount or value of any consideration given by any person inrelation to the obtaining of the option or to the acquisition of the shares.
					This is subject to section 1020.
			The consideration mentioned in subsection (1)(b) does not include—
				the performance of any duties of, or in connection with, the relevantemployment, and
				an amount paid or payable by the employee because of—
				an agreement within paragraph 3A(2) of Schedule 1 to the Social SecurityContributions and Benefits Act [1992 (c. 4)](/id/ukpga/1992/4?view=plain "Goto item of legislation") or of Schedule 1 to the Social Security Contributionsand Benefits (Northern Ireland) Act [1992 (c. 7)](/id/ukpga/1992/7?view=plain"Go to item of legislation"), or
				an election under paragraph 3B of either of those Schedules.
			A just and reasonable apportionment is to be made of any considerationgiven partly in relation to the obtaining of the option or the acquisition ofthe shares and partly in relation to other matters.
		Calculation of relief if shares are restricted or convertible
			If the shares acquired are restricted shares or convertible shares (orboth), the amount of relief to be given is calculated as follows.
				This is subject to section 1020.
			If the shares are restricted shares, the amount of relief is equal to—
				the amount that counts as employment income of the employee under section476 of ITEPA 2003 in relation to the acquisition of the shares, or
				if the option is a qualifying option (within the meaning of the EMI code),the amount that would have so counted apart from the EMI code.
			If the shares are convertible shares, the amount of relief is equal to—
				the amount that counts as employment income of the employee under section476 of ITEPA 2003 in relation to the acquisition of the shares, or
				if the option is a qualifying option (within the meaning of the EMI code),the amount that would have so counted apart from the EMI code;
				and in calculating the employee’s employment income for this purpose themarket value of the shares is to be determined as if they were not convertibleshares.
			For the purposes of subsections (2) and (3)—
				no account is to be taken of any relief under section 481 or 482 of ITEPA2003, and
				“the EMI code” has the meaning given by section 527(3) of that Act.
			If the shares are both restricted and convertible, the total amount ofrelief is whichever is the greater of the amounts of relief given bysubsections (2) and (3) (or, if the amount is the same in each case, thatamount).
			If the employee is dead when the shares are acquired, the amount of reliefis to be calculated as if the employee were alive.
		Reduction in amount of relief
			This section applies if the relevant employment is in relation to both thequalifying business and a business (or part of a business) that is not withinsection 1015(2).
			The amount of relief is to be reduced by a just and reasonable amount.
	Giving of relief
		How the relief is given
			The relief is given for the accounting period in which the shares areacquired.
			The amount of relief is allowed as a deduction in calculating the profitsof the qualifying business for corporation tax purposes (subject tosubsections (3) and (4)).
			If the employing company is a company with investment business (as definedin section 1218), the amount of relief is treated as expenses of management ofthe company.
				But this subsection does not apply if the qualifying business is a propertybusiness (in which case subsection (2) applies instead).
			If the employing company is a company in relation to which section 76 ofICTA (expenses of insurance companies) applies, the amount of relief istreated as expenses payable falling to be brought into account at Step 1 insubsection (7) of that section.
			If the relevant employment is in relation to more than one business (orpart of a business) within section 1015(2), the relief is to be apportioned ona just and reasonable basis.
	Takeovers and transfers of businesses
		Takeover of company whose shares are subject to option
			This section applies if—
				a person (“P”) obtains a qualifying option to acquire shares in a company,
				subsequently there is a takeover of that company,
				P, by agreement with the acquiring company, releases P’s rights under thequalifying option in consideration of P’s obtaining another option (“the newoption”), and
				the new option is an option to acquire shares in a qualifying company.
					Section 1023 explains what is meant by “qualifying option”, “takeover”, “theacquiring company” and “qualifying company”.
			This Chapter applies as if shares acquired pursuant to the new option areacquired pursuant to the qualifying option.
			The company whose shares are subject to the new option is a qualifyingsuccessor company for the purposes of paragraph (f) of condition 3 in section1016 (condition relating to shares acquired).
			In calculating the amount of any relief resulting from this section—
				any consideration given in relation to the obtaining of the new option istreated as consideration given in relation to the obtaining of the qualifyingoption, and
				any consideration given in relation to the acquisition of shares pursuantto the new option is treated as consideration given in relation to theacquisition of shares pursuant to the qualifying option.
				The consideration covered by paragraph (a) does not include the considerationmentioned in subsection (1)(c).
		Supplementary provision for purposes of section 1022
			This section applies for the purposes of section 1022.
			An option is a qualifying option if condition 3 in section 1016 would bemet in relation to shares acquired pursuant to the option.
			There is a takeover of a company when another company (“the acquiringcompany”) acquires control of it.
			The following companies are qualifying companies—
				the acquiring company,
				a company that, when the takeover occurs, is a parent company of theacquiring company,
				a company that, when the takeover occurs, is a member of a consortium thatowns the acquiring company,
				a company that, when the takeover occurs, is a member of a consortium thatowns a parent company of the acquiring company, and
				a company within subsection (5).
			A company (“company A”) is within this subsection if when the takeoveroccurs—
				the acquiring company or a parent company of the acquiring company is amember of a consortium that owns another company (“company B”), and
				company A is—
				a member of that consortium or a parent company of a member of thatconsortium, and
				a member of the same commercial association of companies as company B.
		Transfer of qualifying business by group transfers
			This section applies in relation to relief to be given under this Chapterif—
				during the option period, the whole, or substantially the whole, of thequalifying business is transferred, and
				conditions A and B are met.
			Condition A is that—
				the transfer is a group transfer, or
				if there is more than one transfer, all the transfers are group transfers.
			Condition B is that, as a result of the transfer or transfers, at the endof the option period—
				the whole, or substantially the whole, of the qualifying business iscarried on by one company (“the successor company”) only and that company isnot the employing company, or
				the whole, or substantially the whole, of the qualifying business iscarried on by companies (“the successor companies”) none of which is theemploying company.
			The relief is to be given to—
				the successor company, or
				whichever one of the successor companies is nominated by them,
					instead of the employing company (and references to the employing company insection 1021(3) and (4) are to be read as references to the company to whichthe relief is to be given).
			In this section “the option period” means the period—
				beginning when the option is obtained, and
				ending when the shares are acquired.

Chapter 6Relationship between relief under this Part and other reliefs

Chapter 1Introduction
	Introductory
		Overview of Part
			This Part provides for corporation tax relief for expenditure on researchand development.
			Relief under this Part is in addition to any deduction given under section87 for the expenditure.
			Relief under Chapters 2 to 4 is available to a company which is a small ormedium-sized enterprise, in particular—
				Chapter 2 provides for relief where the cost of in-house direct researchand development or contracted out research and development is incurred by thecompany,
				Chapter 3 provides for relief where research and development is contractedout to the company, and
				Chapter 4 provides for relief for research and development expenditurewhich is subsidised or in respect of which the company is prevented fromobtaining relief under Chapter 2 by the cap on aid imposed by section 1113.
			Relief under Chapter 5 is available to large companies (and insurancecompanies treated as large companies).
			Chapter 6 contains further provision in relation to relief under Chapters 2to 5, in particular—
				section 1081 provides for certain insurance companies to be treated aslarge companies,
				section 1082 contains provision about expenditure of group companies,
				section 1083 contains provision in relation to refunds of certainexpenditure on which relief has been obtained (treating part of those refundsas income chargeable to tax), and
				section 1084 contains an anti-avoidance provision dealing with artificiallyinflated claims for relief or R&D tax credits (as to which, see subsection (7)below).
			Relief under Chapter 7 is available to companies (whether they are small ormedium-sized enterprises or large companies) where expenditure is incurred onvaccine or medicine research.
			Chapters 2 and 7 also provide for the payment of tax credits (“R&D taxcredits”) where a company which is a small or medium-sized enterprise—
				obtains relief under Chapter 2 or 7, and
				makes, or is treated as making, a trading loss.
			Chapter 8 contains provision limiting the amount of relief available underChapter 2 or 7 in relation to expenditure on a particular research anddevelopment project.
			Chapter 9 contains supplementary provision, including definitions.
			For information about the procedure for making claims under this Part seeSchedule 18 to FA 1998, in particular Part 9A of that Schedule (claims for R&Dtax reliefs).
		Relief may be available under more than one Chapter of Part
			Expenditure may be eligible for relief under more than one Chapter of thisPart.
	Interpretation
		“Research and development”
			In this Part “research and development” has the meaning given by section 837Aof ICTA.
		“Relevant research and development”
			In this Part “relevant research and development”, in relation to a company,means research and development—
				related to a trade carried on by the company, or
				from which it is intended that a trade to be carried on by the company willbe derived.
			Research and development related to a trade carried on by a companyincludes—
				research and development which may lead to or facilitate an extension ofthe trade, and
				research and development of a medical nature which has a special relationto the welfare of workers employed in the trade.
			But any reference to “relevant research and development” which applies forthe purposes of Chapter 7 (relief for SMEs and large companies: vaccineresearch etc) is to be read as if subsection (2)(b) were omitted.

Introductory
	Overview of Chapter
		This Chapter provides for relief for companies which are small or medium-sized enterprises for expenditure on—
			in-house direct research and development, or
			contracted out research and development,
				where the cost of the research and development is incurred by the company.
		The reliefs available are—
			an additional deduction under section 1044, or
			a deemed trading loss under section 1045.
		Sections 1046 to 1053 contain provision relevant to the reliefs availableunder this Chapter, namely—
			provision preventing a company from making a claim or election for reliefif it is not a going concern (see section 1046),
			information about elections under section 1045 for a deemed trading loss(see section 1047),
			information about the treatment of a deemed trading loss (see section1048),
			a restriction on consortium relief where relief is obtained (see section1049),
			provision about when a company meets the R&D threshold for the purposes ofobtaining relief (see section 1050), and
			provision about when a company’s expenditure is “qualifying Chapter 2expenditure” for those purposes (see sections 1051 to 1053).
		Sections 1054 to 1062 deal with R&D tax credits which can be claimed if acompany—
			obtains relief under this Chapter, and
			makes, or is treated as making, a trading loss.

Reliefs
	Additional deduction in calculating profits of trade
		A company is entitled to corporation tax relief for an accounting period ifit meets each of conditions A to D.
		Condition A is that the company is a small or medium-sized enterprise inthe period.
		Condition B is that the company meets the R&D threshold in the period (seesection 1050).
		Condition C is that the company carries on a trade in the period.
		Condition D is that the company has qualifying Chapter 2 expenditure whichis allowable as a deduction in calculating for corporation tax purposes theprofits of the trade for the period.
		For the company to obtain the relief it must make a claim.
			See section 1046 (which prevents a company from making a claim if it is not agoing concern).
		The relief is an additional deduction in calculating the profits of thetrade for the period.
		The amount of the additional deduction is 75% of the qualifying Chapter 2expenditure.
		This section is subject to section 1113 (cap on R&D aid in relation to aparticular research and development project).
		For the meaning of “qualifying Chapter 2 expenditure” see section 1051.
	Alternative treatment for pre-trading expenditure: deemed tradingloss
		A company is entitled to corporation tax relief for an accounting period ifit meets conditions A, B and C.
		Condition A is that the company is a small or medium-sized enterprise inthe period.
		Condition B is that the company meets the R&D threshold in the period (seesection 1050).
		Condition C is that the company has incurred qualifying Chapter 2expenditure in the period which—
			is not allowable as a deduction in calculating for corporation tax purposesthe profits of a trade carried on by it at the time the expenditure wasincurred, but
			would have been so allowable had it, at that time, been carrying on a tradeconsisting of the activities in respect of which the expenditure was incurred.
		For the company to obtain the relief it must make an election.
			See section 1046 (which prevents a company from making an election if it isnot a going concern).
		The relief is that the company is treated as if it had made a trading lossin the period.
		The trading loss is equal to 175% of the qualifying Chapter 2 expenditure.
		If a company makes an election under this section in respect of qualifyingChapter 2 expenditure, section 61 (pre-trading expenses) does not apply to theexpenditure.
		This section is subject to section 1113 (cap on R&D aid in relation to aparticular research and development project).
		For the meaning of “qualifying Chapter 2 expenditure” see section 1051.
		See also section 1137, which makes provision about the accounting periodsof a company which is not within the charge to corporation tax.

Reliefs: further provision
	Relief only available where company is going concern
		A company may only make—
			a claim under section 1044, or
			an election under section 1045,
				at a time when it is a going concern.
		For the purposes of this section a company is a going concern if—
			its latest published accounts were prepared on a going concern basis, and
			nothing in those accounts indicates that they were only prepared on thatbasis because of an expectation that the company would receive relief or R&Dtax credits under this Chapter or Chapter 7.
		Section 436(2) of the Companies Act 2006 (meaning of “publication” ofdocuments) has effect for the purposes of this section.
	Elections under section 1045
		An election under section 1045 must specify the accounting period inrespect of which it is made.
		The election must be made by notice in writing to an officer of Revenue andCustoms.
		The notice must be given before the end of the period of two yearsbeginning immediately after the end of the accounting period to which theelection relates.
	Treatment of deemed trading loss under section 1045
		This section applies if under section 1045 a company is treated as making atrading loss in an accounting period.
		The trading loss may not be set off against profits of a precedingaccounting period under section 393A(1)(b) or 393B(3) of ICTA unless thecompany is entitled to relief under section 1045 for the earlier period.
		Subsection (4) applies if—
			the company begins, in the accounting period or a later period, to carry ona trade, and
			the trade is derived from the research and development in relation to whichthe relief mentioned in subsection (1) was obtained.
		In that case, so far as—
			the company has not obtained relief in respect of the trading loss underany other provision, and
			the loss has not been surrendered under section 403(1) of ICTA (surrenderof relief to group or consortium members),
				the trading loss is to be treated as if it were a loss of that trade broughtforward under section 393 of ICTA (relief of trading losses against futuretrading profits).
		Subsection (4) is subject to section 1062 (restriction on losses carriedforward where tax credit claimed).
	Restriction on consortium relief
		This section applies if—
			a company claims relief under section 1044 or elects to obtain relief undersection 1045 in respect of an accounting period,
			at any time during the period the company is owned by a consortium, and
			at least one of the members of the consortium is a large company.
		The amount of the relief obtained in respect of the accounting period maynot be surrendered by the company to another company, for the purposes of aconsortium group relief claim, unless the other company is a small or medium-sized enterprise.
		A “consortium group relief claim” means a claim to group relief undersection 402(3) of ICTA (group relief available between members of consortia).

Threshold
	R&D threshold
		For the purposes of this Chapter a company meets the R&D threshold in anaccounting period if its total qualifying R&D expenditure for the period is atleast—
			£10,000, if the accounting period is a period of 12 months, or
			the amount given by subsection (2), if the accounting period is a period ofless than 12 months.
		The amount referred to in subsection (1)(b) is—
			[![](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_049)](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_049?view=plain)
		where X is the number of days in the accounting period.
		A company’s “total qualifying R&D expenditure” for an accounting period isthe sum of—
			its qualifying Chapter 2 expenditure (see section 1051),
			its qualifying Chapter 3 expenditure (see section 1065), and
			its qualifying Chapter 4 expenditure (see section 1070),
			that is deductible in the period.
		Subsections (5) to (7) apply for the purpose of determining whetherexpenditure is deductible in an accounting period.
		A company’s qualifying Chapter 2 expenditure is deductible in an accountingperiod if—
			it is allowable as a deduction in calculating for corporation tax purposesthe profits for the period of a trade carried on by the company, or
			it would have been allowable as such a deduction had the company, at thetime the expenditure was incurred, been carrying on a trade consisting of theactivities in respect of which it was incurred.
		For the purposes of subsection (5)(a), section 61 (pre-trading expensestreated as incurred when trading begins) is to be ignored.
		Each of the following—
			a company’s qualifying Chapter 3 expenditure, and
			a company’s qualifying Chapter 4 expenditure,
			is deductible in an accounting period if it is allowable as a deduction incalculating for corporation tax purposes the profits for the period of a tradecarried on by the company.
		Expenditure allowable as a deduction for the purposes of subsection (7)includes expenditure so allowable because of section 61 (pre-tradingexpenses).

Qualifying expenditure
	Qualifying Chapter 2 expenditure
		For the purposes of this Part a company’s “qualifying Chapter 2 expenditure”means—
			its qualifying expenditure on in-house direct research and development (seesection 1052), and
			its qualifying expenditure on contracted out research and development (seesection 1053).
	Qualifying expenditure on in-house direct R&D
		A company’s “qualifying expenditure on in-house direct research anddevelopment” means expenditure incurred by it in relation to which each ofconditions A to E is met.
		Condition A is that the expenditure is—
			incurred on staffing costs (see section 1123),
			incurred on software or consumable items (see section 1125),
			qualifying expenditure on externally provided workers (see section 1127),or
			incurred on relevant payments to the subjects of a clinical trial (seesection 1140).
		Condition B is that the expenditure is attributable to relevant researchand development undertaken by the company itself.
		Condition C is that any intellectual property created as a result of theresearch and development to which the expenditure is attributable is, or willbe, vested in the company (whether alone or with other persons).
		Condition D is that the expenditure is not incurred by the company incarrying on activities which are contracted out to the company by any person.
		Condition E is that the expenditure is not subsidised (see section 1138).
		See sections 1124, 1126 and 1132 for provision about when expenditurewithin subsection (2)(a), (b) or (c) is attributable to relevant research anddevelopment.
	Qualifying expenditure on contracted out R&D
		A company’s “qualifying expenditure on contracted out research anddevelopment” means expenditure—
			which is incurred by it in making the qualifying element of a sub-contractor payment (see sections 1134 to 1136), and
			in relation to which each of conditions A to D is met.
		Condition A is that the expenditure is attributable to relevant researchand development undertaken on behalf of the company.
		Condition B is that any intellectual property created as a result of theresearch and development to which the expenditure is attributable is, or willbe, vested in the company (whether alone or with other persons).
		Condition C is that the expenditure is not incurred by the company incarrying on activities which are contracted out to the company by any person.
		Condition D is that the expenditure is not subsidised (see section 1138).
		See sections 1124, 1126 and 1132 for provision about when particular kindsof expenditure are attributable to relevant research and development.

Tax credit: entitlement and payment
	Entitlement to and payment of tax credit
		A company is entitled to an R&D tax credit for an accounting period if ithas a Chapter 2 surrenderable loss in the period (see section 1055).
		For the company to obtain an R&D tax credit in respect of all or part ofthe Chapter 2 surrenderable loss it must make a claim.
			See section 1057 (which prevents a company from making a claim if it is not agoing concern).
		The amount of an R&D tax credit to which the company is entitled isdetermined in accordance with section 1058.
		If a company makes a claim for an R&D tax credit to which it is entitledfor an accounting period, an officer of Revenue and Customs must pay to thecompany the amount of the credit.
		This is subject to section 1060.
		This section is subject to section 1113 (cap on R&D aid in relation to aparticular research and development project).
		See also section 1062, which restricts the carry forward of losses where acompany claims an R&D tax credit.
	Meaning of “Chapter 2 surrenderable loss”
		For the purposes of this Chapter a company has a “Chapter 2 surrenderableloss” if in an accounting period—
			it obtains an additional deduction under section 1044 in calculating theprofits of a trade and it makes a trading loss in that period in the trade, or
			it is treated as making a trading loss under section 1045.
		If relief is obtained under section 1044 the amount of the Chapter 2surrenderable loss is—
			so much of the trading loss as is unrelieved, or
			if less, 175% of the qualifying Chapter 2 expenditure in respect of whichthe relief was obtained.
		If relief is obtained under section 1045 the amount of the Chapter 2surrenderable loss is so much of the trading loss as is unrelieved.
	Amount of trading loss which is “unrelieved”
		This section applies for the purposes of section 1055.
		The amount of a trading loss that is “unrelieved” is the amount of the lossreduced by—
			any relief that was or could have been obtained by the company making aclaim under section 393A(1)(a) of ICTA to set the loss against profits of thesame accounting period,
			any other relief obtained by the company in respect of the loss, includingrelief under section 393A(1)(b) or 393B(3) of that Act (losses set againstprofits of an earlier accounting period), and
			any loss surrendered under section 403(1) of that Act (surrender of reliefto group or consortium members).
		No account is to be taken for this purpose of any losses—
			brought forward from an earlier accounting period under section 393(1) ofICTA, or
			carried back from a later accounting period under section 393A(1)(b) or393B(3) of that Act.
	Tax credit only available where company is going concern
		A company may only make a claim under section 1054 at a time when it is agoing concern.
		If a company ceases to be a going concern after making a claim undersection 1054, it is treated as if it had not made the claim (and accordinglythere is treated as having been no payment of R&D tax credit to carry interestunder section 826 of ICTA).
		Subsection (2) does not apply so far as the claim relates to an amount thatwas paid or applied before the company ceased to be a going concern.
		For the purposes of this section a company is a going concern if—
			its latest published accounts were prepared on a going concern basis, and
			nothing in those accounts indicates that they were only prepared on thatbasis because of an expectation that the company would receive relief or R&Dtax credits under this Chapter or Chapter 7.
		Section 436(2) of the Companies Act 2006 (meaning of “publication” ofdocuments) has effect for the purposes of this section.

Amount of tax credit
	Amount of tax credit
		The amount of the R&D tax credit to which a company is entitled for anaccounting period is—
			14% of the amount of the Chapter 2 surrenderable loss for the period, or
			if less, the total amount of the company’s PAYE and NIC liabilities forpayment periods ending in the accounting period.
		The Treasury may by order replace the percentage for the time beingspecified in subsection (1)(a) with a different percentage.
		An order under subsection (2) may contain incidental, supplemental,consequential and transitional provision and savings.
	Total amount of company’s PAYE and NIC liabilities
		The total amount of the company’s PAYE and NIC liabilities for a paymentperiod is the sum of—
			amount A, and
			amount B.
		Amount A is the amount of income tax for which the company is required toaccount to an officer of Revenue and Customs for the payment period under PAYEregulations.
		In calculating amount A disregard any deduction the company is authorisedto make in respect of child tax credit or working tax credit.
		Amount B is the amount of Class 1 national insurance contributions forwhich the company is required to account to an officer of Revenue and Customsfor the payment period.
		In calculating amount B disregard any deduction the company is authorisedto make in respect of payments of statutory sick pay, statutory maternity pay,child tax credit or working tax credit.

Supplementary
	Payment of tax credit
		This section applies if an R&D tax credit for an accounting period ispayable to a company under this Chapter.
		The amount payable in respect of—
			the R&D tax credit, or
			interest on the credit payable under section 826 of ICTA,
				may be applied in discharging any liability of the company to pay corporationtax.
		So far as the amount is so applied, the duty of the officer of Revenue andCustoms to pay the credit under section 1054(4) is discharged.
		Subsection (5) applies if the company’s tax return for the accountingperiod is enquired into by an officer of Revenue and Customs.
		In that case—
			no payment in respect of the R&D tax credit for the period need be madebefore the officer’s enquiries are completed (see paragraph 32 of Schedule 18to FA 1998), but
			the officer may make a payment on a provisional basis of such amount as theofficer thinks fit.
		No payment need be made in respect of the R&D tax credit if the company hasoutstanding PAYE and NIC liabilities for the period.
		A company has outstanding PAYE and NIC liabilities for an accounting periodif it has not paid to an officer of Revenue and Customs any amount that it isrequired to pay—
			under PAYE regulations, or
			in respect of Class 1 national insurance contributions,
			for payment periods ending in the accounting period.
	Tax credit payment not income of company
		A payment in respect of an R&D tax credit under this Chapter is not income ofthe company for any tax purposes.
	Restriction on losses carried forward where tax credit claimed
		This section applies if a company claims an R&D tax credit to which it isentitled for an accounting period.
		For the purposes of section 393 of ICTA (relief of trading losses againstfuture trading profits) the company’s trading loss for the period is treatedas reduced by the amount of the surrendered loss for the period.
		The “amount of the surrendered loss” for the period means the amount of theChapter 2 surrenderable loss in respect of which the company claims an R&D taxcredit for the period.

Chapter 3Relief for SMEs: R&D sub-contracted to SME
	Relief

	Threshold
		R&D threshold

	Qualifying expenditure
		Qualifying Chapter 3 expenditure
			For the purposes of this Part a company’s “qualifying Chapter 3expenditure” means expenditure incurred by it that meets conditions A and B.

Chapter 4Relief for SMEs: subsidised and capped expenditure on R&D
	Relief
		Additional deduction in calculating profits of trade
			A company is entitled to corporation tax relief for an accounting period ifit meets conditions A, B and C.
			Condition A is that the company is a small or medium-sized enterprise inthe period.
			Condition B is that the company meets the R&D threshold in the period (seesection 1069).
			Condition C is that the company has expenditure within subsection (5) whichis allowable as a deduction in calculating for corporation tax purposes theprofits for the period of a trade carried on by the company.
			The expenditure within this subsection is—
				qualifying Chapter 4 expenditure (see section 1070), and
				capped R&D expenditure (see section 1073).
			For the company to obtain the relief it must make a claim.
			The relief is an additional deduction in calculating the profits of thetrade for the period.
			The amount of the additional deduction is 30% of the expenditure mentionedin subsection (4).
			See section 1083 for provision about refunds of qualifying Chapter 4expenditure and capped R&D expenditure.
	Threshold
		R&D threshold
			If a company meets the R&D threshold in an accounting period for the purposesof Chapter 3 (see section 1064) it also meets the R&D threshold in the periodfor the purposes of this Chapter.
	Qualifying expenditure
		Qualifying Chapter 4 expenditure
			For the purposes of this Part a company’s “qualifying Chapter 4 expenditure”means—
				its subsidised qualifying expenditure on in-house direct research anddevelopment (see section 1071), and
				its subsidised qualifying expenditure on contracted out research anddevelopment (see section 1072).
		Subsidised qualifying expenditure on in-house direct R&D
			A company’s “subsidised qualifying expenditure on in-house direct researchand development” means expenditure incurred by it in relation to which each ofconditions A to E is met.
			Condition A is that the expenditure is subsidised (see section 1138).
			Condition B is that the expenditure is—
				incurred on staffing costs (see section 1123),
				incurred on software or consumable items (see section 1125),
				qualifying expenditure on externally provided workers (see section 1127),or
				incurred on relevant payments to the subjects of a clinical trial (seesection 1140).
			Condition C is that the expenditure is attributable to relevant researchand development undertaken by the company itself.
			Condition D is that any intellectual property created as a result of theresearch and development to which the expenditure is attributable is, or willbe, vested in the company (whether alone or with other persons).
			Condition E is that the expenditure is not incurred by the company incarrying on activities which are contracted out to the company by any person.
			See sections 1124, 1126 and 1132 for provision about when expenditurewithin subsection (3)(a), (b) or (c) is attributable to relevant research anddevelopment.
		Subsidised qualifying expenditure on contracted out R&D
			A company’s “subsidised qualifying expenditure on contracted out researchand development” means expenditure—
				which is incurred by it in making the qualifying element of a sub-contractor payment (see sections 1134 to 1136), and
				in relation to which each of conditions A to F is met.
			Condition A is that the expenditure is subsidised (see section 1138).
			Condition B is that the sub-contractor is—
				a qualifying body,
				an individual, or
				a firm, each member of which is an individual.
			Condition C is that the body, individual or firm concerned undertakes thecontracted out research and development itself.
			Condition D is that the expenditure is attributable to relevant researchand development in relation to the company.
			Condition E is that any intellectual property created as a result of theresearch and development to which the expenditure is attributable is, or willbe, vested in the company (whether alone or with other persons).
			Condition F is that the expenditure is not incurred by the company incarrying on activities which are contracted out to the company by any person.
			Sections 1124, 1126 and 1132 contain provision about when particular kindsof expenditure are attributable to relevant research and development.
		Capped R&D expenditure
			For the purposes of this Part a company’s “capped R&D expenditure” is anyexpenditure—
				in respect of which the company is not entitled to relief under Chapter 2merely because of section 1113 (cap on R&D aid),
				which is not qualifying Chapter 3 expenditure, and
				which would have been qualifying Chapter 5 expenditure had the company beena large company throughout the accounting period in question.

Chapter 5Relief for large companies
	Relief
		Additional deduction in calculating profits of trade
			A company is entitled to corporation tax relief for an accounting period ifit meets conditions A, B and C.
			Condition A is that the company is a large company throughout the period.
			Condition B is that the company meets the R&D threshold in the period (seesection 1075).
			Condition C is that the company carries on a trade in the period.
			For the company to obtain the relief it must make a claim.
			The relief is an additional deduction in calculating the profits of thetrade for the period.
			The amount of the additional deduction is 30% of the qualifying Chapter 5expenditure which—
				is incurred by the company, and
				is allowable as a deduction in calculating for corporation tax purposes theprofits of the trade for the period.
			For the meaning of “qualifying Chapter 5 expenditure” see section 1076.
			See also—
				section 1080 for special provision about insurance companies,
				section 1082 for provision about research and development expenditure ofgroup companies, and
				section 1083 for provision about refunds of qualifying Chapter 5expenditure.
	Threshold
		R&D threshold
			For the purposes of this Chapter a company meets the R&D threshold in anaccounting period if its qualifying Chapter 5 expenditure for the period is atleast—
				£10,000, if the accounting period is a period of 12 months, or
				the amount given by subsection (2), if the accounting period is a period ofless than 12 months.
			The amount referred to in subsection (1)(b) is—
				[![](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_051)](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_051?view=plain)
			where X is the number of days in the accounting period.
			A company’s qualifying Chapter 5 expenditure is “for” the accounting periodif it is allowable as a deduction in calculating for corporation tax purposesthe profits for the period of a trade carried on by the company.
			Expenditure allowable as a deduction for the purposes of subsection (3)includes expenditure so allowable because of section 61 (pre-tradingexpenses).
			For the meaning of “qualifying Chapter 5 expenditure” see section 1076.
	Qualifying expenditure
		Qualifying Chapter 5 expenditure
			For the purposes of this Part a company’s “qualifying Chapter 5 expenditure”means—
				its qualifying expenditure on in-house direct research and development (seesection 1077),
				its qualifying expenditure on contracted out research and development (seesection 1078), and
				its qualifying expenditure on contributions to independent research anddevelopment (see section 1079).
		Qualifying expenditure on in-house direct R&D
			A company’s “qualifying expenditure on in-house direct research anddevelopment” means expenditure incurred by it in relation to which conditionsA, B and C are met.
			Condition A is that the expenditure is—
				incurred on staffing costs (see section 1123),
				incurred on software or consumable items (see section 1125),
				qualifying expenditure on externally provided workers (see section 1127),or
				incurred on relevant payments to the subjects of a clinical trial (seesection 1140).
			Condition B is that the expenditure is attributable to relevant researchand development undertaken by the company itself.
			Condition C is that, if the expenditure is incurred in carrying onactivities contracted out to the company, the activities are contracted outby—
				a large company, or
				any person otherwise than in the course of carrying on a chargeable trade.
			A “chargeable trade” is—
				a trade, profession or vocation carried on wholly or partly in the UnitedKingdom, the profits of which are chargeable to income tax under Chapter 2 ofPart 2 of ITTOIA 2005, or
				a trade carried on wholly or partly in the United Kingdom, the profits ofwhich are chargeable to corporation tax under Chapter 2 of Part 3 of this Act.
			See sections 1124, 1126 and 1132 for provision about when expenditurewithin subsection (2)(a), (b) or (c) is attributable to relevant research anddevelopment.
		Qualifying expenditure on contracted out R&D
			A company’s “qualifying expenditure on contracted out research anddevelopment” means expenditure incurred by it in relation to which each ofconditions A to D is met.
			Condition A is that the expenditure is incurred in making payments to—
				a qualifying body,
				an individual, or
				a firm, each member of which is an individual,
					in respect of research and development contracted out by the company to thebody, individual or firm concerned (“the contracted out R&D”).
			Condition B is that the body, individual or firm concerned undertakes thecontracted out R&D itself.
			Condition C is that the expenditure is attributable to relevant researchand development in relation to the company.
			Condition D is that, if the contracted out R&D is itself contracted out tothe company, it is contracted out by—
				a large company, or
				any person otherwise than in the course of carrying on a chargeable trade.
			A “chargeable trade” is—
				a trade, profession or vocation carried on wholly or partly in the UnitedKingdom, the profits of which are chargeable to income tax under Chapter 2 ofPart 2 of ITTOIA 2005, or
				a trade carried on wholly or partly in the United Kingdom, the profits ofwhich are chargeable to corporation tax under Chapter 2 of Part 3 of this Act.
			See sections 1124, 1126 and 1132 for provision about when particular kindsof expenditure are attributable to relevant research and development.
		Qualifying expenditure on contributions to independent R&D
			A company’s “qualifying expenditure on contributions to independentresearch and development” means expenditure incurred by it in relation towhich each of conditions A to E is met.
			Condition A is that the expenditure is incurred in making payments to—
				a qualifying body,
				an individual, or
				a firm, each member of which is an individual,
					for the purpose of funding research and development carried on by the body,individual or firm concerned (“the funded R&D”).
			Condition B is that the funded R&D is relevant research and development inrelation to the company.
			Condition C is that the funded R&D is not contracted out to the qualifyingbody, individual or firm concerned by another person.
			Condition D is that, if the payment is made to an individual, the companyis not connected with the individual when the payment is made.
			Condition E is that, if the payment is made to a firm (other than aqualifying body), the company is not connected with any member of the firmwhen the payment is made.
	Insurance companies
		Entitlement to relief: I minus E basis

Chapter 6Chapters 2 to 5: further provision
	Insurance companies treated as large companies
		This section applies if an insurance company—
			carries on life assurance business in an accounting period, and
			is a small or medium-sized enterprise in the period.
		For the purposes of Chapters 2 to 5 the company is to be treated as if itwere not such an enterprise in the period.
		Accordingly the company is to be treated as a large company for thepurposes of Chapter 5.
	R&D expenditure of group companies
		This section applies if—
			a company (“A”) incurs expenditure on making a payment to another company(“B”) in respect of activities contracted out by A to B,
			the activities would, if carried out by A, be research and development of A(taken together with A’s other activities), and
			A and B are members of the same group at the time the payment is made.
		If the activities are undertaken by B itself, they are to be treated forthe purposes of Chapters 3 and 5 (so far as it would not otherwise be thecase) as research and development undertaken by B itself.
		If B makes a payment to a third party (“C”), any of the activities—
			contracted out by B to C, and
			undertaken by C itself,
				are to be treated for the purposes of Chapters 3 and 5 (so far as it would nototherwise be the case) as research and development contracted out by B to C.
		For the purposes of this section A and B are members of the same group ifthey are members of the same group of companies for the purposes of Chapter 4of Part 10 of ICTA (group relief).
	Refunds of expenditure treated as income chargeable to tax
		This section applies if a company receives a payment (“the refund”)refunding the whole or any part of expenditure—
			to which subsection (2) applies, and
			in respect of which the company obtains relief under Chapter 3, 4 or 5.
		This subsection applies to—
			qualifying Chapter 3 expenditure to which section 1067 applies (expenditureon sub-contracted R&D not undertaken in-house),
			qualifying Chapter 4 expenditure (subsidised expenditure on R&D),
			capped R&D expenditure, and
			qualifying Chapter 5 expenditure which is—
			qualifying expenditure on contracted out research and development undersection 1078, or
			qualifying expenditure on contributions to independent research anddevelopment under section 1079.
		30% of the refund is to be treated as income of the company chargeable totax under Chapter 2 of Part 3 for the accounting period in which the refund ismade.
		But subsection (3) does not apply if, because of section 1080(4) (grossroll-up business), the relief obtained in respect of the expenditure concernedis an additional deduction in calculating for corporation tax purposes theprofits of gross roll-up business of the company.
		In that case 30% of the refund is to be treated as income which is—
			referable to the gross roll-up business, and
			chargeable, for the accounting period in which the refund is made, underthe charge to corporation tax on income.
	Artificially inflated claims for relief or tax credit
		To the extent that a transaction is attributable to arrangements enteredinto wholly or mainly for a disqualifying purpose, it is to be disregarded forthe purposes mentioned in subsection (2).
		Those purposes are—
			determining for an accounting period relief to which a company is entitledunder Chapters 2 to 5, and
			determining for an accounting period R&D tax credits to which a company isentitled under Chapter 2.
		Arrangements are entered into wholly or mainly for a “disqualifyingpurpose” if their main object, or one of their main objects, is to enable acompany to obtain—
			relief under Chapters 2 to 5 to which it would not otherwise be entitled,
			relief under Chapters 2 to 5 of a greater amount than that to which itwould otherwise be entitled,
			an R&D tax credit under Chapter 2 to which it would not otherwise beentitled, or
			an R&D tax credit under Chapter 2 of a greater amount than that to which itwould otherwise be entitled.
		In this section “arrangements” includes any scheme, agreement orunderstanding, whether or not legally enforceable.

Introductory
	Overview of Chapter
		This Chapter provides for relief for expenditure incurred by companies(whether they are small or medium-sized enterprises or large companies) onresearch and development relating to vaccine or medicine research.
		Section 1086 defines “qualifying R&D activity” (that is, the research anddevelopment in relation to which relief under this Chapter is available).
		The reliefs available are—
			a deduction under section 1087 (the amount of which is determined undersection 1089 or 1091), or
			if the company is a small or medium-sized enterprise, a deemed trading lossunder section 1092.
		Section 1094 prevents a company which is a small or medium-sized enterprisefrom making a claim or election for relief if it is not a going concern.
		Sections 1095 to 1102 contain provision relevant to the reliefs availableunder this Chapter, namely—
			information about elections under section 1092 of a deemed trading loss(see section 1095),
			information about the treatment of a deemed trading loss (see section1096),
			provision about when a company meets the R&D threshold for the purposes ofobtaining relief (see section 1097),
			provision about when a company’s expenditure is “qualifying Chapter 7expenditure” for those purposes and when such expenditure is “for” anaccounting period (see sections 1098 to 1102).
		Sections 1103 to 1111 deal with R&D tax credits which can be claimed if acompany—
			is a small or medium-sized enterprise,
			obtains relief under this Chapter, and
			makes, or is treated as making, a trading loss.
		Section 1112 contains an anti-avoidance provision dealing with artificiallyinflated claims for relief or R&D tax credits under this Chapter.
		See also section 1137 for provision about the accounting periods of acompany which is not within the charge to corporation tax.
	Meaning of “qualifying R&D activity”
		For the purposes of this Chapter “qualifying R&D activity” means researchand development relating to—
			vaccines or medicines for the prevention or treatment of tuberculosis,
			vaccines or medicines for the prevention or treatment of malaria,
			vaccines for the prevention of infection by human immunodeficiency virus,or
			vaccines or medicines for the prevention of the onset, or for thetreatment, of acquired immune deficiency syndrome resulting from infection byhuman immunodeficiency virus in prescribed clades only.
		For the purposes of subsection (1) “prescribed clade” means clade A, C, Dor E or such other clade or clades as the Treasury may by regulationsprescribe.
		The Treasury may make provision by regulations further defining thepurposes referred to in subsection (1).
		In subsection (1) references to vaccines or medicines are to vaccines ormedicines for use in humans.

Reliefs
	Deduction in calculating profits of trade
		A company is entitled to corporation tax relief for an accounting period ifit meets conditions A, B and C.
		Condition A is that the company has incurred expenditure which isqualifying Chapter 7 expenditure for the period.
		Condition B is that the company meets the R&D threshold in the period (seesection 1097).
		Condition C is that the company is carrying on a trade in the period.
		For the company to obtain the relief it must make a claim.
		The relief is a deduction in calculating the profits of the trade for theperiod.
		For the amount of the deduction see—
			section 1089 if the company is a small or medium-sized enterprise in theperiod, and
			section 1091 if the company is a large company throughout the period.
		This section is subject to section 1113 (cap on total R&D aid in relationto a particular research and development project).
		See also—
			section 1088 for the declaration that a large company is required to makein a claim under this section,
			section 1094, which prevents a company which is a small or medium-sizedenterprise from making a claim if it is not a going concern,
			section 1098 for the meaning of “qualifying Chapter 7 expenditure”, and
			sections 1099 and 1100 for the meaning of qualifying Chapter 7 expenditure“for” an accounting period.
	Large companies: declaration about effect of relief
		This section applies if a large company claims relief under section 1087.
		The claim must include a declaration that the availability of the reliefclaimed has resulted in an increase in—
			the amount, scope or speed of the research and development undertaken bythe company, or
			the company’s expenditure on research and development.
	SMEs: amount of deduction
		This section applies if—
			a company makes a claim under section 1087 for relief to which it isentitled for an accounting period, and
			the company is a small or medium-sized enterprise in the period.
		The amount of the deduction under that section is 40% of the company’squalifying Chapter 7 expenditure for the period (see sections 1098 and 1099).
		The deduction is in addition to any other deduction in respect of theexpenditure.
		Subsection (2) is subject to the modification contained in section 1090 forlarger SMEs.
		Expenditure taken into account for the purpose of determining the amount ofthe deduction may include expenditure which is qualifying Chapter 7expenditure for the accounting period because of section 1099(1)(b) (pre-trading expenditure).
		This is despite the fact that the expenditure is unrelated to the tradementioned in section 1087(4).
	Modification of section 1089 for larger SMEs
		Subsection (2) applies if a company which makes a claim under section 1087for relief to which it is entitled for an accounting period—
			is a larger SME in the period, and
			obtains an R&D tax credit for the period under Chapter 2.
		Section 1089 has effect in relation to the company as if for subsection (2)there were substituted—
		The amount of the deduction under that section is 40% of so much of thecompany’s qualifying Chapter 7 expenditure for the period as is expenditure inrespect of which the company is not entitled to relief under Chapter 2.”
	Large companies: amount of deduction
		This section applies if—
			a company makes a claim under section 1087 for relief to which it isentitled for an accounting period, and
			the company is a large company throughout the period.
		The amount of the deduction under that section is the sum of—
			amount A, and
			amount B.
		Amount A is 40% of so much of the company’s qualifying Chapter 7expenditure for the period as is allowable as a deduction in calculating forcorporation tax purposes the profits for the period of a trade carried on bythe company.
		Amount B is 140% of so much of the company’s qualifying Chapter 7expenditure for the period that is not so allowable.
		The deduction is in addition to any other deduction in respect of theexpenditure.
		See sections 1098 and 1100 for the meaning of “qualifying Chapter 7expenditure” and provision about when such expenditure is “for” an accountingperiod.
	SMEs: deemed trading loss for pre-trading expenditure
		A company is entitled to corporation tax relief for an accounting period ifit meets each of conditions A to D.
		Condition A is that the company is a small or medium-sized enterprise inthe period.
		Condition B is that the company meets the R&D threshold in the period (seesection 1097).
		Condition C is that the company has incurred expenditure which isqualifying Chapter 7 expenditure for the period as a result of section1099(1)(b) (“pre-trading qualifying Chapter 7 expenditure”).
		Condition D is that the company is not carrying on a trade in the period.
		For the company to obtain the relief it must make an election.
			See section 1094 (which prevents a company from making an election if it isnot a going concern).
		The relief is that the company is treated as if it had made a trading lossin the period.
		The amount of the trading loss is—
			40% of so much of the pre-trading qualifying Chapter 7 expenditure for theperiod as is expenditure in respect of which the company is also entitled torelief under Chapter 2, and
			140% of so much of the pre-trading qualifying Chapter 7 expenditure for theperiod as is expenditure in respect of which the company is not entitled torelief under Chapter 2,
			but this is subject to section 1093.
		If a company makes an election under this section in respect of pre-tradingqualifying expenditure, section 61 (pre-trading expenses) does not apply tothe expenditure.
		This section is subject to section 1113 (cap on R&D aid in relation to aparticular research and development project).
		See also section 1137 for provision about the accounting periods of acompany which is not within the charge to corporation tax.
		See sections 1098 and 1099 for the meaning of “qualifying Chapter 7expenditure” and provision about when such expenditure is “for” an accountingperiod.
	Modification of section 1092 for larger SMEs
		Subsection (2) applies if a company which makes a claim under section 1087for relief to which it is entitled for an accounting period—
			is a larger SME in the period, and
			obtains an R&D tax credit for the period under Chapter 2.
		Section 1092 has effect in relation to the company as if subsection (8)(a)were omitted.
	Relief only available to SME where company is going concern
		A company which is a small or medium-sized enterprise may only make—
			a claim under section 1087, or
			an election under section 1092,
				at a time when it is a going concern.
		For the purposes of this section a company is a going concern if—
			its latest published accounts were prepared on a going concern basis, and
			nothing in those accounts indicates that they were only prepared on thatbasis because of an expectation that the company would receive relief or R&Dtax credits under Chapter 2 or this Chapter.
		Section 436(2) of the Companies Act 2006 (meaning of “publication” ofdocuments) has effect for the purposes of this section.

Deemed trading loss: further provision
	Elections under section 1092
		An election under section 1092 must specify the accounting period inrespect of which it is made.
		The election must be made by notice in writing to an officer of Revenue andCustoms.
		The notice must be given before the end of the period of two yearsbeginning immediately after the end of the accounting period to which theelection relates.
	Treatment of deemed trading loss under section 1092
		This section applies if under section 1092 a company is treated as making atrading loss in an accounting period.
		The trading loss may not be set off against profits of a precedingaccounting period under section 393A(1)(b) of ICTA unless the company isentitled to relief under section 1092 for the earlier period.
		Subsection (4) applies if—
			the company begins, in the accounting period or a later period, to carry ona trade, and
			the trade is derived from the research and development in relation to whichthe relief mentioned in subsection (1) was obtained.
		In that case, so far as—
			the company has not obtained relief in respect of the trading loss underany other provision, and
			the loss has not been surrendered under section 403(1) of ICTA (surrenderof relief to group or consortium members),
				the trading loss is to be treated as if it were a loss of that trade broughtforward under section 393 of ICTA (relief of trading losses against futuretrading profits).
		Subsection (4) is subject to section 1111 (restriction on losses carriedforward where tax credit claimed).

Threshold
	R&D threshold
		For the purposes of this Chapter a company meets the R&D threshold in anaccounting period if its qualifying Chapter 7 expenditure for the period is atleast—
			£10,000, if the accounting period is a period of 12 months, or
			the amount given by subsection (2), if the accounting period is a period ofless than 12 months.
		The amount referred to in subsection (1)(b) is—
			[![](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_052)](/ukpga/2009/4/images/ukpga_20090004_en_052?view=plain)
		where X is the number of days in the accounting period.
		See sections 1098, 1099 and 1100 for the meaning of “qualifying Chapter 7expenditure” and provision about when such expenditure is “for” an accountingperiod.

Qualifying expenditure
	Meaning of “qualifying Chapter 7 expenditure”
		For the purposes of this Part a company’s “qualifying Chapter 7 expenditure”means—
			its qualifying expenditure on in-house direct research and development (seesection 1101), and
			its qualifying expenditure on contracted out research and development (seesection 1102).
	SMEs: qualifying expenditure “for” an accounting period
		If a company is a small or medium-sized enterprise in an accounting period,its qualifying Chapter 7 expenditure is “for” the period if—
			it is allowable as a deduction in calculating for corporation tax purposesthe profits for the period of a trade carried on by the company, or
			it would have been so allowable had the company, at the time theexpenditure was incurred, been carrying on a trade consisting of theactivities in respect of which it was incurred.
		For the purposes of subsection (1)(a) section 61 (pre-trading expensestreated as incurred when trading begins) is to be ignored.
	Large companies: qualifying expenditure “for” an accounting period
		If a company is a large company throughout an accounting period, itsqualifying Chapter 7 expenditure is “for” the period if it is allowable as adeduction in calculating for corporation tax purposes the profits for theperiod of a trade carried on by the company.
		Expenditure allowable as a deduction for the purposes of subsection (1)includes expenditure so allowable because of section 61 (pre-tradingexpenses).
	Qualifying expenditure on in-house direct R&D
		A company’s “qualifying expenditure on in-house direct research anddevelopment” means expenditure incurred by it in relation to which each ofconditions A to E is met.
		Condition A is that the expenditure is attributable to qualifying R&Dactivity (see section 1086) undertaken by the company itself.
		Condition B is that the qualifying R&D activity to which the expenditure isattributable is relevant research and development in relation to the company.
		Condition C is that the expenditure is—
			incurred on staffing costs (see section 1123),
			incurred on software or consumable items (see section 1125),
			qualifying expenditure on externally provided workers (see section 1127),or
			incurred on relevant payments to the subjects of a clinical trial (seesection 1140).
		Condition D is that the expenditure is not incurred by the company incarrying on activities which are contracted out to the company by any person.
		Condition E is that the expenditure is not subsidised (see section 1138).
		See sections 1124, 1126 and 1132 for provision about when expenditurewithin subsection (4)(a), (b) or (c) is attributable to relevant research anddevelopment.
	Qualifying expenditure on contracted out R&D
		A company’s “qualifying expenditure on contracted out research anddevelopment” means expenditure in relation to which each of conditions A to Dis met.
		Condition A is that the expenditure is incurred in making the qualifyingelement of a sub-contractor payment (see sections 1134 to 1136) to a sub-contractor.
		Condition B is that the expenditure is attributable to qualifying R&Dactivity (see section 1086) undertaken by the sub-contractor itself.
